Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 2, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In 1895, a physicist named 
Wilhelm Roentgen was doing experiments
with a cathode tube, a glass container in which a beam of
electrons lights up a fluorescent window. He had wrapped cardboard around the tube to keep the fluorescent 
light from escaping, when something peculiar happened. Another screen outside the tube
was glowing. In other words, invisible rays
had passed through the cardboard. Wilhelm had no idea what those rays were,
so he called them X-rays, and his discovery eventually won him
a Nobel Prize. Here's what we now know was happening. When high energy electrons
in the cathode tube hit a metal component, they either got slowed down
and released extra energy, or kicked off electrons
from the atoms they hit, which triggered a reshuffling
that again released energy. In both cases, the energy was emitted
in the form of X-rays, which is a type 
of electromagnetic radiation with higher energy than visible light,
and lower energy than Gamma rays. X-rays are powerful enough
to fly through many kinds of matter as if they are semi-transparent, and they're particularly useful 
for medical applications because they can make images of organs,
like bones, without harming them, although they do have a small chance of causing mutations 
in reproductive organs, and tissues like the thyroid, which is why lead aprons are often
used to block them. When X-rays interact with matter,
they collide with electrons. Sometimes, the X-ray transfers all of its
energy to the matter and gets absorbed. Other times, it only transfers 
some of its energy, and the rest is scattered. The frequency of these outcomes depends on how many electrons
the X-rays are likely to hit. Collisions are more likely 
if a material is dense, or if it's made of elements
with higher atomic numbers, which means more electrons. Bones are dense and full of calcium,
which has a relatively high atomic number, so they absorb X-rays pretty well. Soft tissue, on the other hand,
isn't as dense, and contains mostly lower 
atomic number elements, like carbon, hydrogen, and oxygen. So more of the X-rays penetrate tissues
like lungs and muscles, darkening the film. These 2-D pictures are only useful
up to a point, though. When X-rays travel through the body, they can interact with many atoms 
along the path. What is recorded on the film reflects
the sum of all those interactions. It's like trying to print 100 pages
of a novel on a single sheet of paper. To see what's really going on, you would have to take X-ray views
from many angles around the body and use them to construct
an internal image. And that's something 
doctors do all the time in a procedure called a CT,
Computed Tomography scan, another Nobel Prize winning invention. Think of CT like this. With just one X-ray, you might be able to see the density
change due to a solid tumor in a patient, but you wouldn't know how deep
it is beneath the surface. However, if you take X-rays
from multiple angles, you should be able to find
the tumor's position and shape. A CT scanner works by sending
a fan or cone of X-rays through a patient to an array of detectors. The X-ray beam is rotated 
around the patient, and often also moved down 
the patient's body, with the X-ray source tracing
a spiral trajectory. Spiral CT scans produce data
that can be processed into cross sections detailed enough to spot 
anatomical features, tumors, blood clots, and infections. CT scans can even detect 
heart disease and cavities in mummies buried thousands of years ago. So what began as Roentgen's happy accident
has become a medical marvel. Hospitals and clinics now conduct over
100 millions scans each year worldwide to treat diseases and save lives.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: X-rays were discovered by _____
Options: A. Mathematical derivation, B. Experimental accident, C. Technical innovation, D. Philosophical reasoning
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the name of the physicist who discovered X-rays in 1895? Options: A. Albert Einstein, B. Wilhelm Roentgen, C. Marie Curie, D. Niels Bohr Correct Option: B
Question 2: What type of radiation are X-rays? Options: A. Gamma rays, B. Electromagnetic radiation with higher energy than visible light, C. Electromagnetic radiation with lower energy than Gamma rays, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 3: What is a common medical application of X-rays? Options: A. To treat diseases, B. To make images of organs without harming them, C. To diagnose heart disease, D. To detect cavities in mummies Correct Option: B
Question 4: Why do doctors use lead aprons when conducting X-ray scans? Options: A. To make the X-rays stronger, B. To block X-rays and prevent harm to reproductive organs and tissues, C. To improve image quality, D. To reduce radiation exposure Correct Option: B
Question 5: What happens when X-rays interact with matter? Options: A. They get absorbed completely, B. They get scattered completely, C. They collide with electrons and either get absorbed or scattered, D. They have no effect on matter Correct Option: C
Question 6: What is a CT scan? Options: A. A type of X-ray scan, B. A procedure that uses X-rays to construct an internal image, C. A medical device that sends X-rays through a patient, D. A type of radiation therapy Correct Option: B
Question 7: How does a CT scanner work? Options: A. It sends a single X-ray beam through the patient, B. It sends a fan or cone of X-rays through the patient to an array of detectors, C. It uses magnetic fields to detect X-rays, D. It uses ultrasound to detect X-rays Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is the main advantage of spiral CT scans? Options: A. They produce high-quality images, B. They are faster than traditional CT scans, C. They produce detailed cross-sections of the body, D. They are more accurate than traditional CT scans Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is one of the limitations of 2-D X-ray images? Options: A. They are too detailed, B. They are too simple, C. They only show the surface of the body, D. They are too expensive Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is the estimated number of CT scans conducted worldwide each year? Options: A. 10 million, B. 50 million, C. 100 million, D. 500 million Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 1. However, the content of Question 1 does not exactly match the ground truth MCQ, as it asks for the name of the physicist who discovered X-rays, whereas the ground truth MCQ asks about the method of discovery.

A more accurate match would be a generated MCQ that asks about the method of discovery, but such a question is not present in the provided set. If I had to choose from the existing options, I would say that Question 1 is the closest match, but it's not an exact match.

That being said, if I had to choose an index, I would say: 

1

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 2, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. In 1895, a physicist named 
Wilhelm Roentgen was doing experiments
with a cathode tube, a glass container in which a beam of
electrons lights up a fluorescent window. He had wrapped cardboard around the tube to keep the fluorescent 
light from escaping, when something peculiar happened. Another screen outside the tube
was glowing. In other words, invisible rays
had passed through the cardboard. Wilhelm had no idea what those rays were,
so he called them X-rays, and his discovery eventually won him
a Nobel Prize. Here's what we now know was happening. When high energy electrons
in the cathode tube hit a metal component, they either got slowed down
and released extra energy, or kicked off electrons
from the atoms they hit, which triggered a reshuffling
that again released energy. In both cases, the energy was emitted
in the form of X-rays, which is a type 
of electromagnetic radiation with higher energy than visible light,
and lower energy than Gamma rays. X-rays are powerful enough
to fly through many kinds of matter as if they are semi-transparent, and they're particularly useful 
for medical applications because they can make images of organs,
like bones, without harming them, although they do have a small chance of causing mutations 
in reproductive organs, and tissues like the thyroid, which is why lead aprons are often
used to block them. When X-rays interact with matter,
they collide with electrons. Sometimes, the X-ray transfers all of its
energy to the matter and gets absorbed. Other times, it only transfers 
some of its energy, and the rest is scattered. The frequency of these outcomes depends on how many electrons
the X-rays are likely to hit. Collisions are more likely 
if a material is dense, or if it's made of elements
with higher atomic numbers, which means more electrons. Bones are dense and full of calcium,
which has a relatively high atomic number, so they absorb X-rays pretty well. Soft tissue, on the other hand,
isn't as dense, and contains mostly lower 
atomic number elements, like carbon, hydrogen, and oxygen. So more of the X-rays penetrate tissues
like lungs and muscles, darkening the film. These 2-D pictures are only useful
up to a point, though. When X-rays travel through the body, they can interact with many atoms 
along the path. What is recorded on the film reflects
the sum of all those interactions. It's like trying to print 100 pages
of a novel on a single sheet of paper. To see what's really going on, you would have to take X-ray views
from many angles around the body and use them to construct
an internal image. And that's something 
doctors do all the time in a procedure called a CT,
Computed Tomography scan, another Nobel Prize winning invention. Think of CT like this. With just one X-ray, you might be able to see the density
change due to a solid tumor in a patient, but you wouldn't know how deep
it is beneath the surface. However, if you take X-rays
from multiple angles, you should be able to find
the tumor's position and shape. A CT scanner works by sending
a fan or cone of X-rays through a patient to an array of detectors. The X-ray beam is rotated 
around the patient, and often also moved down 
the patient's body, with the X-ray source tracing
a spiral trajectory. Spiral CT scans produce data
that can be processed into cross sections detailed enough to spot 
anatomical features, tumors, blood clots, and infections. CT scans can even detect 
heart disease and cavities in mummies buried thousands of years ago. So what began as Roentgen's happy accident
has become a medical marvel. Hospitals and clinics now conduct over
100 millions scans each year worldwide to treat diseases and save lives.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Many visually opaque objects become _____ under X-ray illumination.
Options: A. Totally transparent, B. Absolutely opaque, C. Semi-transparent, D. Chemically active
Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 2, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In 1895, a physicist named 
Wilhelm Roentgen was doing experiments
with a cathode tube, a glass container in which a beam of
electrons lights up a fluorescent window. He had wrapped cardboard around the tube to keep the fluorescent 
light from escaping, when something peculiar happened. Another screen outside the tube
was glowing. In other words, invisible rays
had passed through the cardboard. Wilhelm had no idea what those rays were,
so he called them X-rays, and his discovery eventually won him
a Nobel Prize. Here's what we now know was happening. When high energy electrons
in the cathode tube hit a metal component, they either got slowed down
and released extra energy, or kicked off electrons
from the atoms they hit, which triggered a reshuffling
that again released energy. In both cases, the energy was emitted
in the form of X-rays, which is a type 
of electromagnetic radiation with higher energy than visible light,
and lower energy than Gamma rays. X-rays are powerful enough
to fly through many kinds of matter as if they are semi-transparent, and they're particularly useful 
for medical applications because they can make images of organs,
like bones, without harming them, although they do have a small chance of causing mutations 
in reproductive organs, and tissues like the thyroid, which is why lead aprons are often
used to block them. When X-rays interact with matter,
they collide with electrons. Sometimes, the X-ray transfers all of its
energy to the matter and gets absorbed. Other times, it only transfers 
some of its energy, and the rest is scattered. The frequency of these outcomes depends on how many electrons
the X-rays are likely to hit. Collisions are more likely 
if a material is dense, or if it's made of elements
with higher atomic numbers, which means more electrons. Bones are dense and full of calcium,
which has a relatively high atomic number, so they absorb X-rays pretty well. Soft tissue, on the other hand,
isn't as dense, and contains mostly lower 
atomic number elements, like carbon, hydrogen, and oxygen. So more of the X-rays penetrate tissues
like lungs and muscles, darkening the film. These 2-D pictures are only useful
up to a point, though. When X-rays travel through the body, they can interact with many atoms 
along the path. What is recorded on the film reflects
the sum of all those interactions. It's like trying to print 100 pages
of a novel on a single sheet of paper. To see what's really going on, you would have to take X-ray views
from many angles around the body and use them to construct
an internal image. And that's something 
doctors do all the time in a procedure called a CT,
Computed Tomography scan, another Nobel Prize winning invention. Think of CT like this. With just one X-ray, you might be able to see the density
change due to a solid tumor in a patient, but you wouldn't know how deep
it is beneath the surface. However, if you take X-rays
from multiple angles, you should be able to find
the tumor's position and shape. A CT scanner works by sending
a fan or cone of X-rays through a patient to an array of detectors. The X-ray beam is rotated 
around the patient, and often also moved down 
the patient's body, with the X-ray source tracing
a spiral trajectory. Spiral CT scans produce data
that can be processed into cross sections detailed enough to spot 
anatomical features, tumors, blood clots, and infections. CT scans can even detect 
heart disease and cavities in mummies buried thousands of years ago. So what began as Roentgen's happy accident
has become a medical marvel. Hospitals and clinics now conduct over
100 millions scans each year worldwide to treat diseases and save lives.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: X-ray scattering happens due to _____
Options: A. Interaction between X-ray photons and material, B. Force between X-ray photons, C. Decay within material under radiation, D. Field inside the X-ray tube
Correct Option: A

Question 6: What is a CT scan? Options: A. A type of X-ray scan, B. A procedure that uses X-rays to construct an internal image, C. A medical device that sends X-rays through a patient, D. A type of radiation therapy Correct Option: B
Question 7: How does a CT scanner work? Options: A. It sends a single X-ray beam through the patient, B. It sends a fan or cone of X-rays through the patient to an array of detectors, C. It uses magnetic fields to detect X-rays, D. It uses ultrasound to detect X-rays Correct Option: B

Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 5: What happens when X-rays interact with matter? 

This question is similar in intent and content to the ground truth MCQ, which asks about X-ray scattering. Although the wording is not identical, both questions deal with the interaction between X-rays and matter, and the correct options (A in the ground truth MCQ and C in Question 5) both describe the collision between X-rays and electrons, resulting in absorption or scattering.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 2, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. **Transcript**:
In 1895, a physicist named 
Wilhelm Roentgen was doing experiments
with a cathode tube, a glass container in which a beam of
electrons lights up a fluorescent window. He had wrapped cardboard around the tube to keep the fluorescent 
light from escaping, when something peculiar happened. Another screen outside the tube
was glowing. In other words, invisible rays
had passed through the cardboard. Wilhelm had no idea what those rays were,
so he called them X-rays, and his discovery eventually won him
a Nobel Prize. Here's what we now know was happening. When high energy electrons
in the cathode tube hit a metal component, they either got slowed down
and released extra energy, or kicked off electrons
from the atoms they hit, which triggered a reshuffling
that again released energy. In both cases, the energy was emitted
in the form of X-rays, which is a type 
of electromagnetic radiation with higher energy than visible light,
and lower energy than Gamma rays. X-rays are powerful enough
to fly through many kinds of matter as if they are semi-transparent, and they're particularly useful 
for medical applications because they can make images of organs,
like bones, without harming them, although they do have a small chance of causing mutations

the X-rays are likely to hit. Collisions are more likely 
if a material is dense, or if it's made of elements

isn't as dense, and contains mostly lower

up to a point, though. When X-rays travel through the body, they can interact with many atoms 
along the path. What is recorded on the film reflects
the sum of all those interactions. It's like trying to print 100 pages
of a novel on a single sheet of paper. To see what's really going on, you would have to take X-ray views
from many angles around the body and use them to construct
an internal image. And that's something 
doctors do all the time in a procedure called a CT,
Computed Tomography scan, another Nobel Prize winning invention. Think of CT like this. With just one X-ray, you might be able to see the density
change due to a solid tumor in a patient, but you wouldn't know how deep
it is beneath the surface. However, if you take X-rays
from multiple angles, you should be able to find
the tumor's position and shape. A CT scanner works by sending

around the patient, and often also moved down 
the patient's body, with the X-ray source tracing
a spiral trajectory. Spiral CT scans produce data
that can be processed into cross sections detailed enough to spot

heart disease and cavities in mummies buried thousands of years ago. So what began as Roentgen's happy accident
has become a medical marvel. Hospitals and clinics now conduct over
100 millions scans each year worldwide to treat diseases and save lives.

Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 2, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In 1895, a physicist named 
Wilhelm Roentgen was doing experiments
with a cathode tube, a glass container in which a beam of
electrons lights up a fluorescent window. He had wrapped cardboard around the tube to keep the fluorescent 
light from escaping, when something peculiar happened. Another screen outside the tube
was glowing. In other words, invisible rays
had passed through the cardboard. Wilhelm had no idea what those rays were,
so he called them X-rays, and his discovery eventually won him
a Nobel Prize. Here's what we now know was happening. When high energy electrons
in the cathode tube hit a metal component, they either got slowed down
and released extra energy, or kicked off electrons
from the atoms they hit, which triggered a reshuffling
that again released energy. In both cases, the energy was emitted
in the form of X-rays, which is a type 
of electromagnetic radiation with higher energy than visible light,
and lower energy than Gamma rays. X-rays are powerful enough
to fly through many kinds of matter as if they are semi-transparent, and they're particularly useful 
for medical applications because they can make images of organs,
like bones, without harming them, although they do have a small chance of causing mutations 
in reproductive organs, and tissues like the thyroid, which is why lead aprons are often
used to block them. When X-rays interact with matter,
they collide with electrons. Sometimes, the X-ray transfers all of its
energy to the matter and gets absorbed. Other times, it only transfers 
some of its energy, and the rest is scattered. The frequency of these outcomes depends on how many electrons
the X-rays are likely to hit. Collisions are more likely 
if a material is dense, or if it's made of elements
with higher atomic numbers, which means more electrons. Bones are dense and full of calcium,
which has a relatively high atomic number, so they absorb X-rays pretty well. Soft tissue, on the other hand,
isn't as dense, and contains mostly lower 
atomic number elements, like carbon, hydrogen, and oxygen. So more of the X-rays penetrate tissues
like lungs and muscles, darkening the film. These 2-D pictures are only useful
up to a point, though. When X-rays travel through the body, they can interact with many atoms 
along the path. What is recorded on the film reflects
the sum of all those interactions. It's like trying to print 100 pages
of a novel on a single sheet of paper. To see what's really going on, you would have to take X-ray views
from many angles around the body and use them to construct
an internal image. And that's something 
doctors do all the time in a procedure called a CT,
Computed Tomography scan, another Nobel Prize winning invention. Think of CT like this. With just one X-ray, you might be able to see the density
change due to a solid tumor in a patient, but you wouldn't know how deep
it is beneath the surface. However, if you take X-rays
from multiple angles, you should be able to find
the tumor's position and shape. A CT scanner works by sending
a fan or cone of X-rays through a patient to an array of detectors. The X-ray beam is rotated 
around the patient, and often also moved down 
the patient's body, with the X-ray source tracing
a spiral trajectory. Spiral CT scans produce data
that can be processed into cross sections detailed enough to spot 
anatomical features, tumors, blood clots, and infections. CT scans can even detect 
heart disease and cavities in mummies buried thousands of years ago. So what began as Roentgen's happy accident
has become a medical marvel. Hospitals and clinics now conduct over
100 millions scans each year worldwide to treat diseases and save lives.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Modern CT data are often collected when the x-ray source moves along _____ around the patient.
Options: A. A straight line, B. A polygon, C. An ellipse, D. A spiral trajectory
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the name of the physicist who discovered X-rays in 1895? Options: A. Albert Einstein, B. Wilhelm Roentgen, C. Marie Curie, D. Niels Bohr Correct Option: B
Question 2: What type of radiation are X-rays? Options: A. Gamma rays, B. Electromagnetic radiation with higher energy than visible light, C. Electromagnetic radiation with lower energy than Gamma rays, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 3: What is a common medical application of X-rays? Options: A. To treat diseases, B. To make images of organs without harming them, C. To diagnose heart disease, D. To detect cavities in mummies Correct Option: B
Question 4: Why do doctors use lead aprons when conducting X-ray scans? Options: A. To make the X-rays stronger, B. To block X-rays and prevent harm to reproductive organs and tissues, C. To improve image quality, D. To reduce radiation exposure Correct Option: B
Question 5: What happens when X-rays interact with matter? Options: A. They get absorbed completely, B. They get scattered completely, C. They collide with electrons and either get absorbed or scattered, D. They have no effect on matter Correct Option: C
Question 6: What is a CT scan? Options: A. A type of X-ray scan, B. A procedure that uses X-rays to construct an internal image, C. A medical device that sends X-rays through a patient, D. A type of radiation therapy Correct Option: B
Question 7: How does a CT scanner work? Options: A. It sends a single X-ray beam through the patient, B. It sends a fan or cone of X-rays through the patient to an array of detectors, C. It uses magnetic fields to detect X-rays, D. It uses ultrasound to detect X-rays Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is the main advantage of spiral CT scans? Options: A. They produce high-quality images, B. They are faster than traditional CT scans, C. They produce detailed cross-sections of the body, D. They are more accurate than traditional CT scans Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is one of the limitations of 2-D X-ray images? Options: A. They are too detailed, B. They are too simple, C. They only show the surface of the body, D. They are too expensive Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is the estimated number of CT scans conducted worldwide each year? Options: A. 10 million, B. 50 million, C. 100 million, D. 500 million Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Death and taxes are famously inevitable,
but what about decomposition? As anyone who's seen a mummy knows, ancient Egyptians went to a lot of trouble
to evade decomposition. So, how successful were they? Living cells constantly renew themselves. Specialized enzymes 
decompose old structures, and the raw materials 
are used to build new ones. But what happens when someone dies? Their dead cells are no longer
able to renew themselves, but the enzymes 
keep breaking everything down. So anyone looking to preserve a body needed to get ahead of those enzymes
before the tissues began to rot. Neurons die quickly, so brains were a lost cause
to Ancient Egyptian mummifiers, which is why, according 
to Greek historian Herodotus, they started the process
by hammering a spike into the skull, mashing up the brain, 
flushing it out the nose and pouring tree resins into the skull
to prevent further decomposition. Brains may decay first,
but decaying guts are much worse. The liver, stomach and intestines
contain digestive enzymes and bacteria, which, upon death, start eating
the corpse from the inside. So the priests removed the lungs
and abdominal organs first. It was difficult to remove the lungs
without damaging the heart, but because the heart was believed
to be the seat of the soul, they treated it with special care. They placed the visceral organs in jars filled with a naturally occurring salt
called natron. Like any salt, natron can prevent decay 
by killing bacteria and preventing the body's natural
digestive enzymes from working. But natron isn't just any salt. It's mainly a mixture 
of two alkaline salts, soda ash and baking soda. Alkaline salts are especially
deadly to bacteria. And they can turn fatty membranes
into a hard, soapy substance, thereby maintaining 
the corpse's structure. After dealing with the internal organs, the priest stuffed the body cavity
with sacks of more natron and washed it clean to disinfect the skin. Then, the corpse was set in a bed
of still more natron for about 35 days 
to preserve its outer flesh. By the time of its removal, the alkaline salts 
had sucked the fluid from the body and formed hard brown clumps. The corpse wasn't putrid, but it didn't exactly smell good, either. So, priests poured tree resin over
the body to seal it, massaged it with a waxy mixture
that included cedar oil, and then wrapped it in linen. Finally, they placed the mummy
in a series of nested coffins and sometimes even a stone sarcophagus. So how successful were 
the ancient Egyptians at evading decay? On one hand, mummies are definitely not
intact human bodies. Their brains have been mashed up
and flushed out, their organs have been removed
and salted like salami, and about half of their remaining
body mass has been drained away. Still, what remains 
is amazingly well-preserved. Even after thousands of years, scientists can perform autopsies 
on mummies to determine their causes of death, and possibly even isolate DNA samples. This has given us new information. For example, it seems that air pollution
was a serious problem in ancient Egypt, probably because of indoor fires 
used to bake bread. Cardiovascular disease was also common,
as was tuberculosis. So ancient Egyptians were somewhat
successful at evading decay. Still, like death, taxes are inevitable. When some mummies were transported,
they were taxed as salted fish.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Decomposition:
Options: A. Is a part of life, B. Starts as soon as cells die, C. Starts when bacteria living in the body start to eat the body, D. Starts when maggots lay eggs on the body
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the main reason why ancient Egyptians went to great lengths to preserve bodies? Options: A. To prevent the body from being buried in the ground, B. To maintain the body's natural digestive processes, C. To prevent decomposition and decay, D. To honor the deceased with elaborate rituals Correct Option: C
Question 2: According to the transcript, what happens to the body's cells after death? Options: A. They continue to renew themselves, B. They start to regenerate, C. They begin to break down and decompose, D. They remain intact Correct Option: C
Question 3: What was the primary method used by ancient Egyptian mummifiers to prevent brain decay? Options: A. By removing the brain and flushing it out the nose, B. By treating the brain with tree resins, C. By hammering a spike into the skull, D. By applying natron to the brain Correct Option: A
Question 4: What is the purpose of using natron to preserve the body? Options: A. To prevent the body's natural digestive processes, B. To kill bacteria and prevent decay, C. To maintain the body's structure, D. To honor the deceased with elaborate rituals Correct Option: B
Question 5: How did the ancient Egyptians treat the heart, which was believed to be the seat of the soul? Options: A. They removed it and treated it with special care, B. They left it intact and did not touch it, C. They replaced it with a stone or wooden replica, D. They ignored it and focused on other organs Correct Option: A
Question 6: What was the result of using natron to preserve the body? Options: A. The body became putrid and decayed quickly, B. The body remained intact and did not decay, C. The body was preserved, but it did not smell good, D. The body was transformed into a different substance Correct Option: C
Question 7: How did the ancient Egyptians transport mummies, and what was the result? Options: A. They were transported on land, and they remained intact, B. They were transported them on water, and they were not affected, C. They were taxed as salted fish when transported, D. They were buried in the ground, and they decayed quickly Correct Option: C
Question 8: What can scientists learn from performing autopsies on mummies? Options: A. The causes of death and possibly even isolate DNA samples, B. The mummies' social status and occupation, C. The mummies' physical characteristics and appearance, D. The mummies' spiritual beliefs and practices Correct Option: A
Question 9: What information has been gained from studying mummies? Options: A. Air pollution was a serious problem in ancient Egypt, B. Cardiovascular disease was not common in ancient Egypt, C. Tuberculosis was not a problem in ancient Egypt, D. The ancient Egyptians did not have any health problems Correct Option: A
Question 10: How successful were the ancient Egyptians at evading decay? Options: A. They were completely successful and the mummies remained intact, B. They were partially successful, but the mummies decayed quickly, C. They were somewhat successful, but the mummies were not preserved well, D. They were not successful at all, and the mummies decayed quickly Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The ground truth MCQ is about decomposition, and the correct option states that decomposition is a part of life. 

Among the generated MCQs, Question 2 is the most similar to the ground truth MCQ. It asks what happens to the body's cells after death, and the correct option states that they begin to break down and decompose. Although the wording is different, the intent and content of Question 2 align with the ground truth MCQ, as both questions relate to the process of decomposition.

Death and taxes are famously inevitable,
but what about decomposition? As anyone who's seen a mummy knows, ancient Egyptians went to a lot of trouble
to evade decomposition. So, how successful were they? Living cells constantly renew themselves. Specialized enzymes 
decompose old structures, and the raw materials 
are used to build new ones. But what happens when someone dies? Their dead cells are no longer
able to renew themselves, but the enzymes 
keep breaking everything down. So anyone looking to preserve a body needed to get ahead of those enzymes
before the tissues began to rot. Neurons die quickly, so brains were a lost cause
to Ancient Egyptian mummifiers, which is why, according 
to Greek historian Herodotus, they started the process
by hammering a spike into the skull, mashing up the brain, 
flushing it out the nose and pouring tree resins into the skull
to prevent further decomposition. Brains may decay first,
but decaying guts are much worse. The liver, stomach and intestines
contain digestive enzymes and bacteria, which, upon death, start eating
the corpse from the inside. So the priests removed the lungs
and abdominal organs first. It was difficult to remove the lungs
without damaging the heart, but because the heart was believed
to be the seat of the soul, they treated it with special care. They placed the visceral organs in jars filled with a naturally occurring salt
called natron. Like any salt, natron can prevent decay 
by killing bacteria and preventing the body's natural
digestive enzymes from working. But natron isn't just any salt. It's mainly a mixture 
of two alkaline salts, soda ash and baking soda. Alkaline salts are especially
deadly to bacteria. And they can turn fatty membranes
into a hard, soapy substance, thereby maintaining 
the corpse's structure. After dealing with the internal organs, the priest stuffed the body cavity
with sacks of more natron and washed it clean to disinfect the skin. Then, the corpse was set in a bed
of still more natron for about 35 days 
to preserve its outer flesh. By the time of its removal, the alkaline salts 
had sucked the fluid from the body and formed hard brown clumps. The corpse wasn't putrid, but it didn't exactly smell good, either. So, priests poured tree resin over
the body to seal it, massaged it with a waxy mixture
that included cedar oil, and then wrapped it in linen. Finally, they placed the mummy
in a series of nested coffins and sometimes even a stone sarcophagus. So how successful were 
the ancient Egyptians at evading decay? On one hand, mummies are definitely not
intact human bodies. Their brains have been mashed up
and flushed out, their organs have been removed
and salted like salami, and about half of their remaining
body mass has been drained away. Still, what remains 
is amazingly well-preserved. Even after thousands of years, scientists can perform autopsies 
on mummies to determine their causes of death, and possibly even isolate DNA samples. This has given us new information. For example, it seems that air pollution
was a serious problem in ancient Egypt, probably because of indoor fires 
used to bake bread. Cardiovascular disease was also common,
as was tuberculosis. So ancient Egyptians were somewhat
successful at evading decay. Still, like death, taxes are inevitable. When some mummies were transported,
they were taxed as salted fish.

Question 2: According to the transcript, what happens to the body's cells after death? Options: A. They continue to renew themselves, B. They start to regenerate, C. They begin to break down and decompose, D. They remain intact Correct Option: C
Question 3: What was the primary method used by ancient Egyptian mummifiers to prevent brain decay? Options: A. By removing the brain and flushing it out the nose, B. By treating the brain with tree resins, C. By hammering a spike into the skull, D. By applying natron to the brain Correct Option: A
Question 4: What is the purpose of using natron to preserve the body? Options: A. To prevent the body's natural digestive processes, B. To kill bacteria and prevent decay, C. To maintain the body's structure, D. To honor the deceased with elaborate rituals Correct Option: B
Question 5: How did the ancient Egyptians treat the heart, which was believed to be the seat of the soul? Options: A. They removed it and treated it with special care, B. They left it intact and did not touch it, C. They replaced it with a stone or wooden replica, D. They ignored it and focused on other organs Correct Option: A
Question 6: What was the result of using natron to preserve the body? Options: A. The body became putrid and decayed quickly, B. The body remained intact and did not decay, C. The body was preserved, but it did not smell good, D. The body was transformed into a different substance Correct Option: C
Question 7: How did the ancient Egyptians transport mummies, and what was the result? Options: A. They were transported on land, and they remained intact, B. They were transported them on water, and they were not affected, C. They were taxed as salted fish when transported, D. They were buried in the ground, and they decayed quickly Correct Option: C
Question 8: What can scientists learn from performing autopsies on mummies? Options: A. The causes of death and possibly even isolate DNA samples, B. The mummies' social status and occupation, C. The mummies' physical characteristics and appearance, D. The mummies' spiritual beliefs and practices Correct Option: A
Question 9: What information has been gained from studying mummies? Options: A. Air pollution was a serious problem in ancient Egypt, B. Cardiovascular disease was not common in ancient Egypt, C. Tuberculosis was not a problem in ancient Egypt, D. The ancient Egyptians did not have any health problems Correct Option: A
Question 10: How successful were the ancient Egyptians at evading decay? Options: A. They were completely successful and the mummies remained intact, B. They were partially successful, but the mummies decayed quickly, C. They were somewhat successful, but the mummies were not preserved well, D. They were not successful at all, and the mummies decayed quickly Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Death and taxes are famously inevitable,
but what about decomposition? As anyone who's seen a mummy knows, ancient Egyptians went to a lot of trouble
to evade decomposition. So, how successful were they? Living cells constantly renew themselves. Specialized enzymes 
decompose old structures, and the raw materials 
are used to build new ones. But what happens when someone dies? Their dead cells are no longer
able to renew themselves, but the enzymes 
keep breaking everything down. So anyone looking to preserve a body needed to get ahead of those enzymes
before the tissues began to rot. Neurons die quickly, so brains were a lost cause
to Ancient Egyptian mummifiers, which is why, according 
to Greek historian Herodotus, they started the process
by hammering a spike into the skull, mashing up the brain, 
flushing it out the nose and pouring tree resins into the skull
to prevent further decomposition. Brains may decay first,
but decaying guts are much worse. The liver, stomach and intestines
contain digestive enzymes and bacteria, which, upon death, start eating
the corpse from the inside. So the priests removed the lungs
and abdominal organs first. It was difficult to remove the lungs
without damaging the heart, but because the heart was believed
to be the seat of the soul, they treated it with special care. They placed the visceral organs in jars filled with a naturally occurring salt
called natron. Like any salt, natron can prevent decay 
by killing bacteria and preventing the body's natural
digestive enzymes from working. But natron isn't just any salt. It's mainly a mixture 
of two alkaline salts, soda ash and baking soda. Alkaline salts are especially
deadly to bacteria. And they can turn fatty membranes
into a hard, soapy substance, thereby maintaining 
the corpse's structure. After dealing with the internal organs, the priest stuffed the body cavity
with sacks of more natron and washed it clean to disinfect the skin. Then, the corpse was set in a bed
of still more natron for about 35 days 
to preserve its outer flesh. By the time of its removal, the alkaline salts 
had sucked the fluid from the body and formed hard brown clumps. The corpse wasn't putrid, but it didn't exactly smell good, either. So, priests poured tree resin over
the body to seal it, massaged it with a waxy mixture
that included cedar oil, and then wrapped it in linen. Finally, they placed the mummy
in a series of nested coffins and sometimes even a stone sarcophagus. So how successful were 
the ancient Egyptians at evading decay? On one hand, mummies are definitely not
intact human bodies. Their brains have been mashed up
and flushed out, their organs have been removed
and salted like salami, and about half of their remaining
body mass has been drained away. Still, what remains 
is amazingly well-preserved. Even after thousands of years, scientists can perform autopsies 
on mummies to determine their causes of death, and possibly even isolate DNA samples. This has given us new information. For example, it seems that air pollution
was a serious problem in ancient Egypt, probably because of indoor fires 
used to bake bread. Cardiovascular disease was also common,
as was tuberculosis. So ancient Egyptians were somewhat
successful at evading decay. Still, like death, taxes are inevitable. When some mummies were transported,
they were taxed as salted fish.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Some mummies were taxed as:
Options: A. Smoked meat, B. Salted meat, C. Smoked fish, D. Salted fish
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the main reason why ancient Egyptians went to great lengths to preserve bodies? Options: A. To prevent the body from being buried in the ground, B. To maintain the body's natural digestive processes, C. To prevent decomposition and decay, D. To honor the deceased with elaborate rituals Correct Option: C
Question 2: According to the transcript, what happens to the body's cells after death? Options: A. They continue to renew themselves, B. They start to regenerate, C. They begin to break down and decompose, D. They remain intact Correct Option: C
Question 3: What was the primary method used by ancient Egyptian mummifiers to prevent brain decay? Options: A. By removing the brain and flushing it out the nose, B. By treating the brain with tree resins, C. By hammering a spike into the skull, D. By applying natron to the brain Correct Option: A
Question 4: What is the purpose of using natron to preserve the body? Options: A. To prevent the body's natural digestive processes, B. To kill bacteria and prevent decay, C. To maintain the body's structure, D. To honor the deceased with elaborate rituals Correct Option: B
Question 5: How did the ancient Egyptians treat the heart, which was believed to be the seat of the soul? Options: A. They removed it and treated it with special care, B. They left it intact and did not touch it, C. They replaced it with a stone or wooden replica, D. They ignored it and focused on other organs Correct Option: A
Question 6: What was the result of using natron to preserve the body? Options: A. The body became putrid and decayed quickly, B. The body remained intact and did not decay, C. The body was preserved, but it did not smell good, D. The body was transformed into a different substance Correct Option: C
Question 7: How did the ancient Egyptians transport mummies, and what was the result? Options: A. They were transported on land, and they remained intact, B. They were transported them on water, and they were not affected, C. They were taxed as salted fish when transported, D. They were buried in the ground, and they decayed quickly Correct Option: C
Question 8: What can scientists learn from performing autopsies on mummies? Options: A. The causes of death and possibly even isolate DNA samples, B. The mummies' social status and occupation, C. The mummies' physical characteristics and appearance, D. The mummies' spiritual beliefs and practices Correct Option: A
Question 9: What information has been gained from studying mummies? Options: A. Air pollution was a serious problem in ancient Egypt, B. Cardiovascular disease was not common in ancient Egypt, C. Tuberculosis was not a problem in ancient Egypt, D. The ancient Egyptians did not have any health problems Correct Option: A
Question 10: How successful were the ancient Egyptians at evading decay? Options: A. They were completely successful and the mummies remained intact, B. They were partially successful, but the mummies decayed quickly, C. They were somewhat successful, but the mummies were not preserved well, D. They were not successful at all, and the mummies decayed quickly Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 5, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Imagine an island where 100 people, all perfect logicians,
are imprisoned by a mad dictator. There's no escape,
except for one strange rule. Any prisoner can approach the guards
at night and ask to leave. If they have green eyes, 
they'll be released. If not, they'll be tossed 
into the volcano. As it happens, 
all 100 prisoners have green eyes, but they've lived there since birth, and the dictator has ensured
they can't learn their own eye color. There are no reflective surfaces, all water is in opaque containers, and most importantly, they're not allowed 
to communicate among themselves. Though they do see each other
during each morning's head count. Nevertheless, they all know no one would
ever risk trying to leave without absolute certainty of success. After much pressure 
from human rights groups, the dictator reluctantly agrees
to let you visit the island and speak to the prisoners
under the following conditions: you may only make one statement, and you cannot tell them 
any new information. What can you say 
to help free the prisoners without incurring the dictator's wrath? After thinking long and hard, you tell the crowd, 
"At least one of you has green eyes." The dictator is suspicious but reassures himself that your statement
couldn't have changed anything. You leave, and life on the island
seems to go on as before. But on the hundredth morning 
after your visit, all the prisoners are gone, each having asked to leave
the previous night. So how did you outsmart the dictator? It might help to realize that the amount
of prisoners is arbitrary. Let's simplify things
by imagining just two, Adria and Bill. Each sees one person with green eyes, and for all they know, 
that could be the only one. For the first night, each stays put. But when they see each other 
still there in the morning, they gain new information. Adria realizes that if Bill had seen
a non-green-eyed person next to him, he would have left the first night after concluding the statement 
could only refer to himself. Bill simultaneously realizes 
the same thing about Adria. The fact that the other person waited tells each prisoner his
or her own eyes must be green. And on the second morning, 
they're both gone. Now imagine a third prisoner. Adria, Bill and Carl each see 
two green-eyed people, but aren't sure if each of the others
is also seeing two green-eyed people, or just one. They wait out the first night as before, but the next morning, 
they still can't be sure. Carl thinks, "If I have non-green eyes, Adria and Bill were just 
watching each other, and will now both leave 
on the second night." But when he sees both 
of them the third morning, he realizes they must 
have been watching him, too. Adria and Bill have each 
been going through the same process, and they all leave on the third night. Using this sort of inductive reasoning, we can see that the pattern will repeat
no matter how many prisoners you add. The key is the concept 
of common knowledge, coined by philosopher David Lewis. The new information was not contained
in your statement itself, but in telling it to everyone 
simultaneously. Now, besides knowing at least one
of them has green eyes, each prisoner also knows 
that everyone else is keeping track of all the green-eyed people they can see, and that each of them 
also knows this, and so on. What any given prisoner doesn't know is whether they themselves are one
of the green-eyed people the others are keeping track of until as many nights have passed
as the number of prisoners on the island. Of course, you could have spared
the prisoners 98 days on the island by telling them at least 99 of you
have green eyes, but when mad dictators are involved,
you're best off with a good headstart.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What proportion of the prisoners have green eyes?
Options: A. 25%, B. 100%, C. 50%
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the main condition set by the dictator for the visitor to speak to the prisoners? Options: A. The visitor can only speak to one prisoner at a time., B. The visitor can only make one statement to the entire group., C. The visitor can only speak to the prisoners during the day., D. The visitor can only communicate with the dictator. Correct Option: B
Question 2: What is the key factor that allows the prisoners to determine their own eye color? Options: A. The fact that they can see each other during the morning head count., B. The fact that they can communicate with each other., C. The fact that they see each other still present on the first night., D. The fact that they know the dictator's rule. Correct Option: C
Question 3: What would happen if the visitor told the prisoners that at least 99 of them have green eyes? Options: A. The prisoners would leave immediately., B. The prisoners would wait for 99 nights before leaving., C. The prisoners would still wait for 98 days before leaving., D. The prisoners would never leave. Correct Option: C
Question 4: What is the concept that allows the prisoners to figure out their own eye color? Options: A. Common knowledge., B. Inductive reasoning., C. Deductive reasoning., D. Intuition. Correct Option: A
Question 5: What is the main idea behind the visitor's statement to the prisoners? Options: A. To tell them that they are all going to be released., B. To tell them that at least one of them has green eyes., C. To tell them that they will be kept on the island forever., D. To tell them that they will be tortured. Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the reason why the prisoners can't figure out their own eye color on the first night? Options: A. Because they don't see each other during the morning head count., B. Because they can't communicate with each other., C. Because they see each other still present on the first night., D. Because they don't know the dictator's rule. Correct Option: C
Question 7: What would happen if the prisoners were able to communicate with each other? Options: A. They would still be able to figure out their own eye color., B. They would be able to leave the island immediately., C. They would be able to figure out their own eye color more quickly., D. They would never be able to figure out their own eye color. Correct Option: D
Question 8: What is the relationship between the number of prisoners and the number of nights they wait before leaving? Options: A. The number of prisoners is directly proportional to the number of nights they wait., B. The number of prisoners is inversely proportional to the number of nights they wait., C. The number of prisoners is equal to the number of nights they wait., D. The number of prisoners has no relationship to the number of nights they wait. Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the main idea behind the concept of common knowledge? Options: A. It is the knowledge that everyone has the same information., B. It is the knowledge that everyone knows that everyone else knows the same information., C. It is the knowledge that everyone knows that everyone else knows that everyone else knows the same information., D. It is the knowledge that everyone has different information. Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is the advantage of the visitor's statement to the prisoners? Options: A. It allows them to leave the island immediately., B. It allows them to figure out their own eye color more quickly., C. It allows them to wait for 98 days before leaving., D. It allows them to spare 98 days on the island. Correct Option: D


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that none of the generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question content and options. However, I can suggest a generated MCQ that is somewhat related to the ground truth MCQ.

The ground truth MCQ asks about the proportion of prisoners with green eyes. While none of the generated MCQs ask this exact question, Question 3 mentions a scenario where the visitor tells the prisoners that at least 99 of them have green eyes. This question is related to the ground truth MCQ in the sense that it discusses the proportion of prisoners with green eyes, but it does not directly ask about the proportion.

If I had to choose a generated MCQ that is most similar to the ground truth MCQ, I would choose Question 3. However, please note that this is not a direct match, and the question content and options are not identical.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 3

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Why don't the prisoners just take a chance and try to leave?
Options: A. They'll be killed if they turn out to be wrong, B. They're afraid of embarrassing themselves, C. They don't know they can leave
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the main condition set by the dictator for the visitor to speak to the prisoners? Options: A. The visitor can only speak to one prisoner at a time., B. Because they can't communicate with each other., C. Because they see each other still present on the first night., D. Because they don't know the dictator's rule. Correct Option: C
Question 7: What would happen if the prisoners were able to communicate with each other? Options: A. They would still be able to figure out their own eye color., B. They would be able to leave the island immediately., C. They would be able to figure out their own eye color more quickly., D. They would never be able to figure out their own eye color. Correct Option: D
Question 8: What is the relationship between the number of prisoners and the number of nights they wait before leaving? Options: A. The number of prisoners is directly proportional to the number of nights they wait., B. The number of prisoners is inversely proportional to the number of nights they wait., C. The number of prisoners is equal to the number of nights they wait., D. The number of prisoners has no relationship to the number of nights they wait. Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the main idea behind the concept of common knowledge? Options: A. It is the knowledge that everyone has the same information., B. It is the knowledge that everyone knows that everyone else knows the same information., C. It is the knowledge that everyone knows that everyone else knows that everyone else knows the same information., D. It is the knowledge that everyone has different information. Correct Option: C

It allows them to figure out their own eye color more quickly., C. It allows them to wait for 98 days before leaving., D. It allows them to spare 98 days on the island. Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 5, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Imagine an island where 100 people, all perfect logicians,
are imprisoned by a mad dictator. There's no escape,
except for one strange rule. Any prisoner can approach the guards
at night and ask to leave. If they have green eyes, 
they'll be released. If not, they'll be tossed 
into the volcano. As it happens, 
all 100 prisoners have green eyes, but they've lived there since birth, and the dictator has ensured
they can't learn their own eye color. There are no reflective surfaces, all water is in opaque containers, and most importantly, they're not allowed 
to communicate among themselves. Though they do see each other
during each morning's head count. Nevertheless, they all know no one would
ever risk trying to leave without absolute certainty of success. After much pressure 
from human rights groups, the dictator reluctantly agrees
to let you visit the island and speak to the prisoners
under the following conditions: you may only make one statement, and you cannot tell them 
any new information. What can you say 
to help free the prisoners without incurring the dictator's wrath? After thinking long and hard, you tell the crowd, 
"At least one of you has green eyes." The dictator is suspicious but reassures himself that your statement
couldn't have changed anything. You leave, and life on the island
seems to go on as before. But on the hundredth morning 
after your visit, all the prisoners are gone, each having asked to leave
the previous night. So how did you outsmart the dictator? It might help to realize that the amount
of prisoners is arbitrary. Let's simplify things
by imagining just two, Adria and Bill. Each sees one person with green eyes, and for all they know, 
that could be the only one. For the first night, each stays put. But when they see each other 
still there in the morning, they gain new information. Adria realizes that if Bill had seen
a non-green-eyed person next to him, he would have left the first night after concluding the statement 
could only refer to himself. Bill simultaneously realizes 
the same thing about Adria. The fact that the other person waited tells each prisoner his
or her own eyes must be green. And on the second morning, 
they're both gone. Now imagine a third prisoner. Adria, Bill and Carl each see 
two green-eyed people, but aren't sure if each of the others
is also seeing two green-eyed people, or just one. They wait out the first night as before, but the next morning, 
they still can't be sure. Carl thinks, "If I have non-green eyes, Adria and Bill were just 
watching each other, and will now both leave 
on the second night." But when he sees both 
of them the third morning, he realizes they must 
have been watching him, too. Adria and Bill have each 
been going through the same process, and they all leave on the third night. Using this sort of inductive reasoning, we can see that the pattern will repeat
no matter how many prisoners you add. The key is the concept 
of common knowledge, coined by philosopher David Lewis. The new information was not contained
in your statement itself, but in telling it to everyone 
simultaneously. Now, besides knowing at least one
of them has green eyes, each prisoner also knows 
that everyone else is keeping track of all the green-eyed people they can see, and that each of them 
also knows this, and so on. What any given prisoner doesn't know is whether they themselves are one
of the green-eyed people the others are keeping track of until as many nights have passed
as the number of prisoners on the island. Of course, you could have spared
the prisoners 98 days on the island by telling them at least 99 of you
have green eyes, but when mad dictators are involved,
you're best off with a good headstart.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which is NOT a condition limiting how you speak to the prisoners?
Options: A. The prisoners all leave the island on the 100th night, B. Some prisoners try to leave but are thrown into the volcano, C. The prisoners remain on the island because your statement changed nothing
Correct Option: A

The visitor can only make one statement to the entire group., C. The visitor can only speak to the prisoners during the day., D. The visitor can only communicate with the dictator. Correct Option: B
Question 2: What is the key factor that allows the prisoners to determine their own eye color? Options: A. The fact that they can see each other during the morning head count., B. The fact that they can communicate with each other., C. The fact that they see each other still present on the first night., D. The fact that they know the dictator's rule. Correct Option: C
Question 3: What would happen if the visitor told the prisoners that at least 99 of them have green eyes? Options: A. The prisoners would leave immediately., B. The prisoners would wait for 99 nights before leaving., C. The prisoners would still wait for 98 days before leaving., D. The prisoners would never leave. Correct Option: C

To tell them that at least one of them has green eyes., C. To tell them that they will be kept on the island forever., D. To tell them that they will be tortured. Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the reason why the prisoners can't figure out their own eye color on the first night? Options: A. Because they don't see each other during the morning head count., B. Because they can't communicate with each other., C. Because they see each other still present on the first night., D. Because they don't know the dictator's rule. Correct Option: C

They would be able to leave the island immediately., C. They would be able to figure out their own eye color more quickly., D. They would never be able to figure out their own eye color. Question 8: What is the relationship between the number of prisoners and the number of nights they wait before leaving? Options: A. The number of prisoners is directly proportional to the number of nights they wait., B. The number of prisoners is inversely proportional to the number of nights they wait., C. Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 6, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In 1997, 
in a game between France and Brazil, a young Brazilian player
named Roberto Carlos set up for a 35 meter free kick. With no direct line to the goal, Carlos decided to attempt 
the seemingly impossible. His kick sent the ball flying
wide of the players, but just before going out of bounds,
it hooked to the left and soared into the goal. According to Newton's first law of motion, an object will move 
in the same direction and velocity until a force is applied on it. When Carlos kicked the ball,
he gave it direction and velocity, but what force made the ball swerve and score one of the most magnificent 
goals in the history of the sport? The trick was in the spin. Carlos placed his kick
at the lower right corner of the ball, sending it high and to the right,
but also rotating around its axis. The ball started its flight
in an apparently direct route, with air flowing on both sides
and slowing it down. On one side, the air moved in the opposite
direction to the ball's spin, causing increased pressure, while on the other side, the air moved
in the same direction as the spin, creating an area of lower pressure. That difference made the ball curve
towards the lower pressure zone. This phenomenon is called
the Magnus effect. This type of kick, 
often referred to as a banana kick, is attempted regularly, and it is one of the elements
that makes the beautiful game beautiful. But curving the ball 
with the precision needed to both bend around the wall
and back into the goal is difficult. Too high and it soars over the goal. Too low and it hits the ground 
before curving. Too wide and it never reaches the goal. Not wide enough 
and the defenders intercept it. Too slow and it hooks too early,
or not at all. Too fast and it hooks too late. The same physics make it possible to score another 
apparently impossible goal, an unassisted corner kick. The Magnus effect was first documented
by Sir Isaac Newton after he noticed it while playing a game
of tennis back in 1670. It also applies to golf balls,
frisbees and baseballs. In every case, the same thing happens. The ball's spin creates a pressure 
differential in the surrounding air flow that curves it 
in the direction of the spin. And here's a question. Could you theoretically 
kick a ball hard enough to make it boomerang 
all the way around back to you? Sadly, no. Even if the ball didn't 
disintegrate on impact, or hit any obstacles, as the air slowed it, the angle of its deflection 
would increase, causing it to spiral into smaller 
and smaller circles until finally stopping. And just to get that spiral, you'd have to make the ball spin
over 15 times faster than Carlos's immortal kick. So good luck with that.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which physics principal underlies the banana kick?
Options: A. Newton's first law of motion, B. Ballistic movement, C. The Magnus effect, D. The Maxwell effect
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What type of kick is often referred to as a "banana kick" due to its curved trajectory? Options: A. Chip kick, B. Banana kick, C. Through ball, D. Free kick Correct Option: B
Question 2: According to Newton's first law of motion, what happens to an object when no force is applied to it? Options: A. It changes direction, B. It slows down, C. It moves in the same direction and velocity, D. It stops Correct Option: C
Question 3: What is the name of the phenomenon responsible for the ball's curve due to spin? Options: A. Magnus effect, B. Bernoulli's principle, C. Newton's second law, D. Aerodynamic effect Correct Option: A
Question 4: In the scenario described, what would happen if the ball was kicked too high? Options: A. It would hook too early, B. It would hit the ground before curving, C. It would soar over the goal, D. It would deflect too late Correct Option: C
Question 5: Who first documented the Magnus effect while playing a game of tennis? Options: A. Roberto Carlos, B. Sir Isaac Newton, C. Albert Einstein, D. Galileo Galilei Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the minimum speed required for a ball to boomerang back to the kicker? Options: A. Over 5 times faster than Carlos's kick, B. Over 10 times faster than Carlos's kick, C. Over 15 times faster than Carlos's kick, D. Over 20 times faster than Carlos's kick Correct Option: C
Question 7: What would happen if the ball was kicked too wide? Options: A. It would never reach the goal, B. It would hit the defenders, C. It would hook too early, D. It would deflect too late Correct Option: A
Question 8: According to the transcript, what is the main reason why curving the ball with precision is difficult? Options: A. The Magnus effect is too strong, B. The ball is too heavy, C. The ball's spin creates a pressure differential in the surrounding air flow, D. The ball is too light Correct Option: C
Question 9: In which sport did Sir Isaac Newton first notice the Magnus effect? Options: A. Football, B. Tennis, C. Golf, D. Baseball Correct Option: B
Question 10: What would happen if the ball was kicked with too much spin? Options: A. It would hook too early, B. It would hook too late, C. It would not curve at all, D. It would spiral into smaller and smaller circles until finally stopping Correct Option: D


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 3. 

This question directly addresses the physics principle underlying the banana kick, which is the Magnus effect. The question content and options are similar to the ground truth MCQ, with the correct option being the Magnus effect. 

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 3.

wide of the players, but just before going out of bounds,

but also rotating around its axis. The ball started its flight
in an apparently direct route, with air flowing on both sides
and slowing it down. On one side, the air moved in the opposite

often referred to as a banana kick, is attempted regularly, and it is one of the elements

in the direction of the spin. And here's a question. Could you theoretically

all the way around back to you? Sadly, no. Even if the ball didn't 
disintegrate on impact, or hit any obstacles, as the air slowed it, the angle of its deflection 
would increase, causing it to spiral into smaller 
and smaller circles until finally stopping. And just to get that spiral, you'd have to make the ball spin
over 15 times faster than Carlos's immortal kick. So good luck with that.

Options: A. Air pressure, B. Momentum, C. Gravity, D. Friction
Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 6, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In 1997, 
in a game between France and Brazil, a young Brazilian player
named Roberto Carlos set up for a 35 meter free kick. With no direct line to the goal, Carlos decided to attempt 
the seemingly impossible. His kick sent the ball flying
wide of the players, but just before going out of bounds,
it hooked to the left and soared into the goal. According to Newton's first law of motion, an object will move 
in the same direction and velocity until a force is applied on it. When Carlos kicked the ball,
he gave it direction and velocity, but what force made the ball swerve and score one of the most magnificent 
goals in the history of the sport? The trick was in the spin. Carlos placed his kick
at the lower right corner of the ball, sending it high and to the right,
but also rotating around its axis. The ball started its flight
in an apparently direct route, with air flowing on both sides
and slowing it down. On one side, the air moved in the opposite
direction to the ball's spin, causing increased pressure, while on the other side, the air moved
in the same direction as the spin, creating an area of lower pressure. That difference made the ball curve
towards the lower pressure zone. This phenomenon is called
the Magnus effect. This type of kick, 
often referred to as a banana kick, is attempted regularly, and it is one of the elements
that makes the beautiful game beautiful. But curving the ball 
with the precision needed to both bend around the wall
and back into the goal is difficult. Too high and it soars over the goal. Too low and it hits the ground 
before curving. Too wide and it never reaches the goal. Not wide enough 
and the defenders intercept it. Too slow and it hooks too early,
or not at all. Too fast and it hooks too late. The same physics make it possible to score another 
apparently impossible goal, an unassisted corner kick. The Magnus effect was first documented
by Sir Isaac Newton after he noticed it while playing a game
of tennis back in 1670. It also applies to golf balls,
frisbees and baseballs. In every case, the same thing happens. The ball's spin creates a pressure 
differential in the surrounding air flow that curves it 
in the direction of the spin. And here's a question. Could you theoretically 
kick a ball hard enough to make it boomerang 
all the way around back to you? Sadly, no. Even if the ball didn't 
disintegrate on impact, or hit any obstacles, as the air slowed it, the angle of its deflection 
would increase, causing it to spiral into smaller 
and smaller circles until finally stopping. And just to get that spiral, you'd have to make the ball spin
over 15 times faster than Carlos's immortal kick. So good luck with that.
