Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 8, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Just now, somewhere in the universe,
a star exploded. There goes another one. In fact, a supernova occurs every second
or so in the observable universe, and there is one on average
every 25 to 50 years in a galaxy the size 
and age of the Milky Way. Yet we've never actually been able
to watch one happen from its first violent moments. Of course, how would we? There are hundreds of billions
of stars close enough that we could watch 
the supernova explosion break through the surface of the star. But we'd have to have our best telescopes
focused on the right one at precisely the right time
to get meaningful data. Suffice it to say, the odds of that
happening are astronomically low. But what if we could anticipate 
a supernova before its light reached us? That may seem impossible. After all, nothing travels faster
than the speed of light, right? As far as we know, yes. But in a race, fast doesn't matter
if you take a detour while someone else beelines it
for the finish line. For exactly that reason, photons don't win 
the supernova race to Earth. Neutrinos do. Here's why. There are two types of supernova. Type 1 is when a star accumulates
so much matter from a neighboring star, that a runaway nuclear reaction ignites
and causes it to explode. In type 2, the star runs out 
of nuclear fuel, so the gravitational forces pulling in overwhelm the quantum mechanical 
forces pushing out, and the stellar core collapses under
its own weight in a hundredth of a second. While the outer reaches of the star
are unaffected by the collapsed core, the inner edges accelerate 
through the void, smash into the core,
and rebound to launch the explosion. In both of these scenarios, the star expels an unparalleled
amount of energy, as well as a great deal of matter. In fact, all atoms heavier than nickel,
including elements like gold and silver, only form in supernova reactions. In type 2 supernovae, about 1% of the energy 
consists of photons, which we know of as light, while 99% radiates out as neutrinos, the elementary particles that are known
for rarely interacting with anything. Starting from the center of the star, the exploding matter takes 
tens of minutes, or even hours, or in rare cases, several days, to reach
and break through the surface of the star. However, the neutrinos, 
thanks to their non-interactivity, take a much more direct route. By the time there is any visible change
in the star's suface, the neutrinos typically have a several
hour head start over the photons. That's why astronomers and physicists have been able to set up a project
called SNEWS, the Supernova Early Warning System. When detectors around the world
pick up bursts of neutrinos, they send messages 
to a central computer in New York. If multiple detectors receive 
similar signals within ten seconds, SNEWS will trigger an alert warning
that a supernova is imminent. Aided by some distance and direction
information from the neutrino detectors, the amateur astronomers 
and scientists alike will scan the skies and share information to quickly identify 
the new galactic supernova and turn the world's major 
telescopes in that direction. The last supernova that sent detectable
neutrinos to Earth was in 1987 on the edge of the Tarantula Nebula in the large Magellanic Cloud,
a nearby galaxy. Its neutrinos reached Earth about
three hours ahead of the visible light. We're due for another one any day now,
and when that happens, SNEWS should give you the opportunity
to be among the first to witness something that no human has ever seen before.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Metals heavier than what element are formed in supernovae?
Options: A. Copper, B. Silver, C. Nickel, D. Gold
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the frequency of supernovae in the observable universe? Options: A. One per year, B. One per second, C. One every 25 to 50 years in a galaxy the size and age of the Milky Way, D. One per decade Correct Option: B
Question 2: What type of particles are known for rarely interacting with anything, and are used in the Supernova Early Warning System? Options: A. Photons, B. Neutrinos, C. Electrons, D. Protons Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the main difference between Type 1 and Type 2 supernovae? Options: A. Type 1 occurs when a star accumulates matter from a neighboring star, while Type 2 occurs when a star runs out of nuclear fuel, B. Type 1 occurs when a star runs out of nuclear fuel, while Type 2 occurs when a star accumulates matter from a neighboring star, C. Type 1 occurs when a star explodes due to a runaway nuclear reaction, while Type 2 occurs when a star collapses under its own weight, D. Type 1 occurs when a star is born, while Type 2 occurs when a star dies Correct Option: A
Question 4: If a supernova were to occur in a nearby galaxy, how long would it take for the neutrinos to reach Earth? Options: A. Several minutes, B. Several hours, C. Several days, D. Several weeks Correct Option: B
Question 5: What would happen if multiple detectors around the world pick up bursts of neutrinos within ten seconds of each other? Options: A. The Supernova Early Warning System would trigger an alert warning that a supernova is imminent, B. The Supernova Early Warning System would send a message to a central computer in New York to verify the signal, C. The Supernova Early Warning System would turn the world's major telescopes in the direction of the suspected supernova, D. The Supernova Early Warning System would ignore the signal and wait for further confirmation Correct Option: A
Question 6: What is the main advantage of using neutrinos to detect supernovae instead of photons? Options: A. Neutrinos travel faster than photons, B. Neutrinos take a more direct route to Earth than photons, C. Neutrinos interact more frequently with matter than photons, D. Neutrinos are more easily detected than photons Correct Option: B
Question 7: What elements are formed in supernova reactions, and what percentage of the energy consists of photons in Type 2 supernovae? Options: A. All elements heavier than nickel, and 99% of the energy consists of photons, B. All elements heavier than nickel, and 1% of the energy consists of photons, C. Only elements lighter than nickel, and 99% of the energy consists of photons, D. Only elements lighter than nickel, and 1% of the energy consists of photons Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is the purpose of the Supernova Early Warning System, and how does it work? Options: A. To detect supernovae and alert astronomers and scientists to the possibility of a new galactic supernova, B. To study the properties of supernovae and learn more about their behavior, C. To predict the timing and location of supernovae, D. To ignore supernovae and focus on other astronomical events Correct Option: A
Question 9: Why is the Supernova Early Warning System important, and what benefits does it provide to astronomers and scientists? Options: A. It allows astronomers and scientists to detect supernovae and study their properties in real-time, B. It provides a warning system for supernovae, allowing astronomers and scientists to prepare for the event, C. It helps to predict the timing and location of supernovae, allowing astronomers and scientists to focus on other events, D. It ignores supernovae and focuses on other astronomical events Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the significance of the 1987's supernova in the large Magellanic Cloud, and what does it tell us about the Supernova Early Warning System? Options: A. It was the first supernova detected by the Supernova Early Warning System, B. It was the first supernova detected by neutrinos, C. It was the first supernova detected by photons, D. It was the last supernova detected by the Supernova Early Warning System Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 7. 

This question asks about the elements formed in supernova reactions and the percentage of energy that consists of photons in Type 2 supernovae. Although it does not exactly match the ground truth MCQ, which only asks about the metals heavier than what element are formed in supernovae, it does contain the relevant information and provides the correct answer (nickel) as part of its options.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 7.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 8, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Just now, somewhere in the universe,
a star exploded. There goes another one. In fact, a supernova occurs every second
or so in the observable universe, and there is one on average
every 25 to 50 years in a galaxy the size 
and age of the Milky Way. Yet we've never actually been able
to watch one happen from its first violent moments. Of course, how would we? There are hundreds of billions
of stars close enough that we could watch 
the supernova explosion break through the surface of the star. But we'd have to have our best telescopes
focused on the right one at precisely the right time
to get meaningful data. Suffice it to say, the odds of that
happening are astronomically low. But what if we could anticipate 
a supernova before its light reached us? That may seem impossible. After all, nothing travels faster
than the speed of light, right? As far as we know, yes. But in a race, fast doesn't matter
if you take a detour while someone else beelines it
for the finish line. For exactly that reason, photons don't win 
the supernova race to Earth. Neutrinos do. Here's why. There are two types of supernova. Type 1 is when a star accumulates
so much matter from a neighboring star, that a runaway nuclear reaction ignites
and causes it to explode. In type 2, the star runs out 
of nuclear fuel, so the gravitational forces pulling in overwhelm the quantum mechanical 
forces pushing out, and the stellar core collapses under
its own weight in a hundredth of a second. While the outer reaches of the star
are unaffected by the collapsed core, the inner edges accelerate 
through the void, smash into the core,
and rebound to launch the explosion. In both of these scenarios, the star expels an unparalleled
amount of energy, as well as a great deal of matter. In fact, all atoms heavier than nickel,
including elements like gold and silver, only form in supernova reactions. In type 2 supernovae, about 1% of the energy 
consists of photons, which we know of as light, while 99% radiates out as neutrinos, the elementary particles that are known
for rarely interacting with anything. Starting from the center of the star, the exploding matter takes 
tens of minutes, or even hours, or in rare cases, several days, to reach
and break through the surface of the star. However, the neutrinos, 
thanks to their non-interactivity, take a much more direct route. By the time there is any visible change
in the star's suface, the neutrinos typically have a several
hour head start over the photons. That's why astronomers and physicists have been able to set up a project
called SNEWS, the Supernova Early Warning System. When detectors around the world
pick up bursts of neutrinos, they send messages 
to a central computer in New York. If multiple detectors receive 
similar signals within ten seconds, SNEWS will trigger an alert warning
that a supernova is imminent. Aided by some distance and direction
information from the neutrino detectors, the amateur astronomers 
and scientists alike will scan the skies and share information to quickly identify 
the new galactic supernova and turn the world's major 
telescopes in that direction. The last supernova that sent detectable
neutrinos to Earth was in 1987 on the edge of the Tarantula Nebula in the large Magellanic Cloud,
a nearby galaxy. Its neutrinos reached Earth about
three hours ahead of the visible light. We're due for another one any day now,
and when that happens, SNEWS should give you the opportunity
to be among the first to witness something that no human has ever seen before.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What percentage of energy from a supernova explosion is expelled as neutrinos?
Options: A. 1, B. 90, C. 99, D. 10
Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 8, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. **Transcript**:
Just now, somewhere in the universe,
a star exploded. There goes another one. In fact, a supernova occurs every second
or so in the observable universe, and there is one on average
every 25 to 50 years in a galaxy the size 
and age of the Milky Way. Yet we've never actually been able
to watch one happen from its first violent moments. Of course, how would we? There are hundreds of billions
of stars close enough that we could watch 
the supernova explosion break through the surface of the star. But we'd have to have our best telescopes
focused on the right one at precisely the right time
to get meaningful data. Suffice it to say, the odds of that
happening are astronomically low. But what if we could anticipate 
a supernova before its light reached us? That may seem impossible. After all, nothing travels faster
than the speed of light, right? As far as we know, yes. But in a race, fast doesn't matter
if you take a detour while someone else beelines it
for the finish line. For exactly that reason, photons don't win 
the supernova race to Earth. Neutrinos do. Here's why. There are two types of supernova. Type 1 is when a star accumulates
so much matter from a neighboring star, that a runaway nuclear reaction ignites
and causes it to explode. In type 2, the star runs out 
of nuclear fuel, so the gravitational forces pulling in overwhelm the quantum mechanical 
forces pushing out, and the stellar core collapses under
its own weight in a hundredth of a second. While the outer reaches of the star
are unaffected by the collapsed core, the inner edges accelerate 
through the void, smash into the core,
and rebound to launch the explosion. In both of these scenarios, the star expels an unparalleled
amount of energy, as well as a great deal of matter. In fact, all atoms heavier than nickel,
including elements like gold and silver, only form in supernova reactions. In type 2 supernovae, about 1% of the energy 
consists of photons, which we know of as light, while 99% radiates out as neutrinos, the elementary particles that are known
for rarely interacting with anything. Starting from the center of the star, the exploding matter takes 
tens of minutes, or even hours, or in rare cases, several days, to reach
and break through the surface of the star. However, the neutrinos, 
thanks to their non-interactivity, take a much more direct route. By the time there is any visible change
in the star's suface, the neutrinos typically have a several
hour head start over the photons. That's why astronomers and physicists have been able to set up a project
called SNEWS, the Supernova Early Warning System. When detectors around the world
pick up bursts of neutrinos, they send messages 
to a central computer in New York. If multiple detectors receive 
similar signals within ten seconds, SNEWS will trigger an alert warning
that a supernova is imminent. Aided by some distance and direction
information from the neutrino detectors, the amateur astronomers 
and scientists alike will scan the skies and share information to quickly identify 
the new galactic supernova and turn the world's major 
telescopes in that direction. The last supernova that sent detectable
neutrinos to Earth was in 1987 on the edge of the Tarantula Nebula in the large Magellanic Cloud,
a nearby galaxy. Its neutrinos reached Earth about
three hours ahead of the visible light. We're due for another one any day now,
and when that happens, SNEWS should give you the opportunity
to be among the first to witness something that no human has ever seen before.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: A supernova is defined as _____.
Options: A. Meteor, B. Satellite crash, C. Planet explosion, D. Death of a star
Correct Option: D

Just now, somewhere in the universe,
a star exploded. There goes another one. In fact, a supernova occurs every second
or so in the observable universe, and there is one on average
every 25 to 50 years in a galaxy the size 
and age of the Milky Way. Yet we've never actually been able
to watch one happen from its first violent moments. Of course, how would we? There are hundreds of billions
of stars close enough that we could watch

happening are astronomically low. But what if we could anticipate

thanks to their non-interactivity, take a much more direct route. By the time there is any visible change

hour head start over the photons. That's why astronomers and physicists have been able to set up a project

Options: A. 1987, B. 1999, C. 1978, D. 1969
Correct Option: A

It allows astronomers and scientists to detect supernovae and study their properties in real-time, B. It provides a warning system for supernovae, allowing astronomers and scientists to prepare for the event, C. It helps to predict the timing and location of supernovae, allowing astronomers and scientists to focus on other events, D. It ignores supernovae and focuses on other astronomical events Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the significance of the 1987's supernova in the large Magellanic Cloud, and what does it tell us about the Supernova Early Warning System? Options: A. It was the first supernova detected by the Supernova Early Warning System, B. It was the first supernova detected by neutrinos, C. It was the first supernova detected by photons, D. It was the last supernova detected by the Supernova Early Warning System Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question content and options. However, Question 10 is the most similar in terms of intent and topic. It mentions a specific supernova event in 1987, which is also the correct answer in the ground truth MCQ.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 10

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
If you ask people whether 
they think stealing is wrong, most of them would answer, "Yes." And yet, in 2013, organizations
all over the world lost an estimated total
of 3.7 trillion dollars to fraud, which includes crimes like embezzlement, pyramid schemes, and false insurance claims. This wasn't just the work
of a few bad apples. The truth is that many people
are susceptible not only to the temptation 
to commit fraud but to convincing themselves
that they've done nothing wrong. So why does fraud happen? While individual motivations 
may differ from case to case, the fraud triangle, a model developed
by criminologist Donald Cressey, shows three conditions 
that make fraud likely: pressure, opportunity,
and rationalization. Pressure is often what motivates someone
to engage in fraud to begin with. It could be a personal debt, an addiction, an earnings quota, a sudden job loss, or an illness in the family. As for opportunity, many people
in both public and private sectors have access to tools that enable them
to commit and conceal fraud: corporate credit cards, internal company data, or control over the budget. The combination of pressure and being exposed to such opportunities
on a daily basis can create a strong temptation. But even with these two elements, most fraud still requires rationalization. Many fraudsters are first time offenders, so in order to commit an act
most would regard as wrong, they need to justify it to themselves. Some feel entitled to the money
because they are underpaid and overworked and others believe 
their fraud is victimless, perhaps even planning to return
the money once their crisis is resolved. Some of the most common types of fraud don't even register as such
to the perpetrator. Examples include employees
fudging time sheets or expense reports, taxpayers failing to report cash earnings, or service providers overbilling
insurance companies. Though these may seem small, and can sometimes
only involve hundreds of dollars, they all contribute to the big picture. And then there's fraud on a massive scale. In 2003, Italian dairy food giant 
Parmalat went bankrupt after it was found to have fabricated
a 4 billion dollar bank account and falsified financial statements to hide the fact that its subsidiaries
had been losing money. Because it was family controlled, corporate governance 
and regulator supervision were difficult, and the company likely hoped 
that the losses could be recouped before anyone found out. And it's not just corporate greed. Governments and non-profits
are also susceptible to fraud. During her time as City Comptroller
for Dixon, Illinois, Rita Crundwell embezzled 
over 53 million dollars. Rita was one of the country's leading 
quarter horse breeders and winner of 52 world championships. But the cost of maintaining the herd
ran to 200,000 dollars per month. Because her position gave her complete
control over city finances, she was easily able to divert money to an account she used 
for private expenses, and the scheme went 
unnoticed for 20 years. It is believed that Crundwell
felt entitled to a lavish lifestyle based on her position, and the notoriety 
her winnings brought to the city. It's tempting to think of fraud
as a victimless crime because corporations 
and civic institutions aren't people. But fraud harms real people
in virtually every case: the employees of Parmalat 
who lost their jobs, the citizens of Dixon whose taxes
subsidized horse breeding, the customers of companies
which raise their prices to offset losses. Sometimes the effects are obvious
and devestating, like when Bernie Madoff caused thousands
of people to lose their life savings. But often they're subtle
and not easy to untangle. Yet someone, 
somewhere is left holding the bill.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The three indices of the fraud triangle are pressure, opportunity and _____.
Options: A. Critical thinking, B. Rationalization, C. Justification, D. Validation
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the estimated total amount of money lost to fraud worldwide in 2013? Options: A. 1 trillion dollars, B. 3.7 trillion dollars, C. 5 trillion dollars, D. 10 trillion dollars Correct Option: B
Question 2: According to the transcript, what are the three conditions that make fraud likely, as described by the fraud triangle model? Options: A. Opportunity, pressure, and rationalization, B. Opportunity, rationalization, and greed, C. Pressure, rationalization, and entitlement, D. Opportunity, greed, and entitlement Correct Option: A
Question 3: In what year did Italian dairy food giant Parmalat go bankrupt due to fabricated financial statements and a falsified bank account? Options: A. 2002, B. 2003, C. 2004, D. 2005 Correct Option: B
Question 4: What was the amount of money embezzled by Rita Crundwell, the City Comptroller for Dixon, Illinois? Options: A. 10 million dollars, B. 20 million dollars, C. 30 million dollars, D. 53 million dollars Correct Option: D
Question 5: According to the transcript, what is one reason why many people are susceptible to the temptation to commit fraud? Options: A. They are underpaid and overworked, B. They are entitled to the money, C. They feel victimless, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 6: What is the name of the criminologist who developed the fraud triangle model? Options: A. Donald Cressey, B. Bernie Madoff, C. Rita Crundwell, D. Parmalat Correct Option: A
Question 7: In what way did the employees of Parmalat suffer as a result of the company's bankruptcy? Options: A. They lost their jobs, B. They lost their life savings, C. They lost their homes, D. They lost their health insurance Correct Option: A
Question 8: According to the transcript, what is one reason why Rita Crundwell felt entitled to a lavish lifestyle? Options: A. She was underpaid and overworked, B. She was a winner of 52 world championships, C. She was the City Comptroller for Dixon, Illinois, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 9: What is one way in which fraud can harm real people, as described in the transcript? Options: A. By causing them to lose their life savings, B. By causing them to lose their jobs, C. By causing them to lose their health insurance, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 10: According to the transcript, who is often left holding the bill for the effects of fraud? Options: A. The perpetrator, B. The victim, C. Someone, somewhere, D. The company Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 2. 

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent (identifying the three conditions of the fraud triangle), options (listing the correct combination of conditions), and content (referencing the fraud triangle model). Although the question phrasing is not identical, the overall meaning and purpose of the question are the same.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 2.

somewhere is left holding the bill.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 4

ran to 200,000 dollars per month. Because her position gave her complete
control over city finances, she was easily able to divert money to an account she used 
for private expenses, and the scheme went 
unnoticed for 20 years. It is believed that Crundwell
felt entitled to a lavish lifestyle based on her position, and the notoriety 
her winnings brought to the city. It's tempting to think of fraud
as a victimless crime because corporations 
and civic institutions aren't people. But fraud harms real people
in virtually every case: the employees of Parmalat 
who lost their jobs, the citizens of Dixon whose taxes
subsidized horse breeding, the customers of companies
which raise their prices to offset losses. Sometimes the effects are obvious
and devestating, like when Bernie Madoff caused thousands
of people to lose their life savings. But often they're subtle
and not easy to untangle. Yet someone, 
somewhere is left holding the bill.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Sometimes the effects of fraud are not obvious and are hard to untangle.
Options: A. True, B. False
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the estimated total amount of money lost to fraud worldwide in 2013? Options: A. 1 trillion dollars, B. 3.7 trillion dollars, C. 5 trillion dollars, D. 10 trillion dollars Correct Option: B
Question 2: According to the transcript, what are the three conditions that make fraud likely, as described by the fraud triangle model? Options: A. Opportunity, pressure, and rationalization, B. Opportunity, rationalization, and greed, C. Pressure, rationalization, and entitlement, D. Opportunity, greed, and entitlement Correct Option: A
Question 3: In what year did Italian dairy food giant Parmalat go bankrupt due to fabricated financial statements and a falsified bank account? Options: A. 2002, B. 2003, C. 2004, D. 2005 Correct Option: B
Question 4: What was the amount of money embezzled by Rita Crundwell, the City Comptroller for Dixon, Illinois? Options: A. 10 million dollars, B. 20 million dollars, C. 30 million dollars, D. 53 million dollars Correct Option: D
Question 5: According to the transcript, what is one reason why many people are susceptible to the temptation to commit fraud? Options: A. They are underpaid and overworked, B. They are entitled to the money, C. They feel victimless, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 6: What is the name of the criminologist who developed the fraud triangle model? Options: A. Donald Cressey, B. Bernie Madoff, C. Rita Crundwell, D. Parmalat Correct Option: A
Question 7: In what way did the employees of Parmalat suffer as a result of the company's bankruptcy? Options: A. They lost their jobs, B. They lost their life savings, C. They lost their homes, D. They lost their health insurance Correct Option: A
Question 8: According to the transcript, what is one reason why Rita Crundwell felt entitled to a lavish lifestyle? Options: A. She was underpaid and overworked, B. She was a winner of 52 world championships, C. She was the City Comptroller for Dixon, Illinois, D. All of the above Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Michael Jordan once said, "I don't know whether I'll fly or not. I know that when I'm in the air sometimes I feel like I don't ever
have to come down." But thanks to Isaac Newton, we know that what goes up
must eventually come down. In fact, the human limit 
on a flat surface for hang time, or the time from when your feet leave
the ground to when they touch down again, is only about one second, and, yes, that even includes his airness, whose infamous dunk 
from the free throw line has been calculated at .92 seconds. And, of course, gravity is what's making it
so hard to stay in the air longer. Earth's gravity pulls all nearby objects
towards the planet's surface, accelerating them 
at 9.8 meters per second squared. As soon as you jump,
gravity is already pulling you back down. Using what we know about gravity, we can derive a fairly simple equation
that models hang time. This equation states that the height
of a falling object above a surface is equal to the object's initial height
from the surface plus its initial velocity multiplied by how many seconds
it's been in the air, plus half of the 
gravitational acceleration multiplied by the square of the number
of seconds spent in the air. Now we can use this equation to model
MJ's free throw dunk. Say MJ starts, as one does,
at zero meters off the ground, and jumps with an initial vertical
velocity of 4.51 meters per second. Let's see what happens if we model
this equation on a coordinate grid. Since the formula is quadratic, the relationship between height
and time spent in the air has the shape of a parabola. So what does it tell us about MJ's dunk? Well, the parabola's vertex shows us
his maximum height off the ground at 1.038 meters, and the X-intercepts tell us 
when he took off and when he landed,
with the difference being the hang time. It looks like Earth's gravity
makes it pretty hard for even MJ to get some solid hang time. But what if he were playing an away game
somewhere else, somewhere far? Well, the gravitational acceleration
on our nearest planetary neighbor, Venus, is 8.87 meters per second squared, 
pretty similar to Earth's. If Michael jumped here with the same
force as he did back on Earth, he would be able to get more 
than a meter off the ground, giving him a hang time 
of a little over one second. The competition on Jupiter
with its gravitational pull of 24.92 meters per second squared
would be much less entertaining. Here, Michael wouldn't even
get a half meter off the ground, and would remain airborne
a mere .41 seconds. But a game on the moon
would be quite spectacular. MJ could take off from behind half court, jumping over six meters high, and his hang time of over 
five and half seconds, would be long enough for anyone
to believe he could fly.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is the acceleration due to gravity on Earth?
Options: A. -9.8 meters per second squared, B. -4.9 meters per second squared, C. -32 meters per second squared, D. -16 meters per second squared
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the name of the scientist who helped us understand that what goes up must eventually come down? Options: A. Albert Einstein, B. Isaac Newton, C. Galileo Galilei, D. Michael Jordan Correct Option: B
Question 2: According to the transcript, what is the human limit on a flat surface for hang time? Options: A. 2 seconds, B. 1 second, C. 3 seconds, D. 4 seconds Correct Option: B
Question 3: If Michael Jordan were to jump on the moon, how long would his hang time be? Options: A. Less than 1 second, B. 1-2 seconds, C. 2-3 seconds, D. Over 5 seconds Correct Option: D
Question 4: What is the gravitational acceleration on Earth? Options: A. 8.87 meters per second squared, B. 9.8 meters per second squared, C. 10.5 meters per second squared, D. 11.2 meters per second squared Correct Option: B
Question 5: According to the transcript, what is the equation that models hang time? Options: A. h = v0t + 0.5gt^2, B. h = v0t - 0.5gt^2, C. h = v0t + gt^2, D. h = v0t - gt^2 Correct Option: A
Question 6: If Michael Jordan starts at zero meters off the ground and jumps with an initial vertical velocity of 4.51 meters per second, what is his maximum height off the ground? Options: A. 1.038 meters, B. 1.2 meters, C. 1.5 meters, D. 2 meters Correct Option: A
Question 7: What would happen if Michael Jordan jumped on Jupiter with its gravitational pull of 24.92 meters per second squared? Options: A. He would be able to get more than a meter off the ground, B. He would be able to get half a meter off the ground, C. He wouldn't even get a half meter off the ground, D. He would be able to fly Correct Option: C
Question 8: According to the transcript, what is the relationship between height and time spent in the air when modeling MJ's free throw dunk? Options: A. Linear, B. Quadratic, C. Exponential, D. Logarithmic Correct Option: B
Question 9: If Michael Jordan were to play an away game on Venus, what would he be able to get more hang time than on Earth? Options: A. Yes, B. No, C. Maybe, D. It depends Correct Option: A
Question 10: What can be concluded about Michael Jordan's ability to get hang time on different planets? Options: A. He would be able to get more hang time on Earth than on any other planet, B. He would be able to get more hang time on Jupiter than on any other planet, C. He would be able to get more hang time on Venus than on Earth, D. He would be able to get more hang time on the moon than on any other planet Correct Option: D


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 4. 

This question has the same intent as the ground truth MCQ, which is to ask about the acceleration due to gravity on Earth. The options provided in Question 4 are also similar to those in the ground truth MCQ, with the correct answer being 9.8 meters per second squared.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 4.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:

Options: A. h=8.87t^2-4.5t, B. h=-8.87t^2+4.5t, C. h=-4.44t^2+4.5t, D. h=4.44t^2-4.5t
Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Michael Jordan once said, "I don't know whether I'll fly or not. I know that when I'm in the air sometimes I feel like I don't ever
have to come down." But thanks to Isaac Newton, we know that what goes up
must eventually come down. In fact, the human limit 
on a flat surface for hang time, or the time from when your feet leave
the ground to when they touch down again, is only about one second, and, yes, that even includes his airness, whose infamous dunk 
from the free throw line has been calculated at .92 seconds. And, of course, gravity is what's making it
so hard to stay in the air longer. Earth's gravity pulls all nearby objects
towards the planet's surface, accelerating them 
at 9.8 meters per second squared. As soon as you jump,
gravity is already pulling you back down. Using what we know about gravity, we can derive a fairly simple equation
that models hang time. This equation states that the height
of a falling object above a surface is equal to the object's initial height
from the surface plus its initial velocity multiplied by how many seconds
it's been in the air, plus half of the 
gravitational acceleration multiplied by the square of the number
of seconds spent in the air. Now we can use this equation to model
MJ's free throw dunk. Say MJ starts, as one does,
at zero meters off the ground, and jumps with an initial vertical
velocity of 4.51 meters per second. Let's see what happens if we model
this equation on a coordinate grid. Since the formula is quadratic, the relationship between height
and time spent in the air has the shape of a parabola. So what does it tell us about MJ's dunk? Well, the parabola's vertex shows us
his maximum height off the ground at 1.038 meters, and the X-intercepts tell us 
when he took off and when he landed,
with the difference being the hang time. It looks like Earth's gravity
makes it pretty hard for even MJ to get some solid hang time. But what if he were playing an away game
somewhere else, somewhere far? Well, the gravitational acceleration
on our nearest planetary neighbor, Venus, is 8.87 meters per second squared, 
pretty similar to Earth's. If Michael jumped here with the same
force as he did back on Earth, he would be able to get more 
than a meter off the ground, giving him a hang time 
of a little over one second. The competition on Jupiter
with its gravitational pull of 24.92 meters per second squared
would be much less entertaining. Here, Michael wouldn't even
get a half meter off the ground, and would remain airborne
a mere .41 seconds. But a game on the moon
would be quite spectacular. MJ could take off from behind half court, jumping over six meters high, and his hang time of over 
five and half seconds, would be long enough for anyone
to believe he could fly.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What type of function is the relationship between height and hang time?
Options: A. Linear, B. Exponential, C. Quadratic, D. Increasing
Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Michael Jordan once said, "I don't know whether I'll fly or not. I know that when I'm in the air sometimes I feel like I don't ever
have to come down." But thanks to Isaac Newton, we know that what goes up
must eventually come down. In fact, the human limit 
on a flat surface for hang time, or the time from when your feet leave
the ground to when they touch down again, is only about one second, and, yes, that even includes his airness, whose infamous dunk 
from the free throw line has been calculated at .92 seconds. And, of course, gravity is what's making it
so hard to stay in the air longer. Earth's gravity pulls all nearby objects
towards the planet's surface, accelerating them 
at 9.8 meters per second squared. As soon as you jump,
gravity is already pulling you back down. Using what we know about gravity, we can derive a fairly simple equation
that models hang time. This equation states that the height
of a falling object above a surface is equal to the object's initial height
from the surface plus its initial velocity multiplied by how many seconds
it's been in the air, plus half of the 
gravitational acceleration multiplied by the square of the number
of seconds spent in the air. Now we can use this equation to model
MJ's free throw dunk. Say MJ starts, as one does,
at zero meters off the ground, and jumps with an initial vertical
velocity of 4.51 meters per second. Let's see what happens if we model
this equation on a coordinate grid. Since the formula is quadratic, the relationship between height
and time spent in the air has the shape of a parabola. So what does it tell us about MJ's dunk? Well, the parabola's vertex shows us
his maximum height off the ground at 1.038 meters, and the X-intercepts tell us 
when he took off and when he landed,
with the difference being the hang time. It looks like Earth's gravity
makes it pretty hard for even MJ to get some solid hang time. But what if he were playing an away game
somewhere else, somewhere far? Well, the gravitational acceleration
on our nearest planetary neighbor, Venus, is 8.87 meters per second squared, 
pretty similar to Earth's. If Michael jumped here with the same
force as he did back on Earth, he would be able to get more 
than a meter off the ground, giving him a hang time 
of a little over one second. The competition on Jupiter
with its gravitational pull of 24.92 meters per second squared
would be much less entertaining. Here, Michael wouldn't even
get a half meter off the ground, and would remain airborne
a mere .41 seconds. But a game on the moon
would be quite spectacular. MJ could take off from behind half court, jumping over six meters high, and his hang time of over 
five and half seconds, would be long enough for anyone
to believe he could fly.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:

Options: A. .92=-4.9(0)^2+4.51(0), B. .92=-9.8(0)^2+4.51(0), C. 0=-4.9(.92)^2+4.51(.92), D. 0=-9.8(.92)^2+4.51(.92)
Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Michael Jordan once said, "I don't know whether I'll fly or not. I know that when I'm in the air sometimes I feel like I don't ever
have to come down." But thanks to Isaac Newton, we know that what goes up
must eventually come down. In fact, the human limit 
on a flat surface for hang time, or the time from when your feet leave
the ground to when they touch down again, is only about one second, and, yes, that even includes his airness, whose infamous dunk 
from the free throw line has been calculated at .92 seconds. And, of course, gravity is what's making it
so hard to stay in the air longer. Earth's gravity pulls all nearby objects
towards the planet's surface, accelerating them 
at 9.8 meters per second squared. As soon as you jump,
gravity is already pulling you back down. Using what we know about gravity, we can derive a fairly simple equation
that models hang time. This equation states that the height
of a falling object above a surface is equal to the object's initial height
from the surface plus its initial velocity multiplied by how many seconds
it's been in the air, plus half of the 
gravitational acceleration multiplied by the square of the number
of seconds spent in the air. Now we can use this equation to model
MJ's free throw dunk. Say MJ starts, as one does,
at zero meters off the ground, and jumps with an initial vertical
velocity of 4.51 meters per second. Let's see what happens if we model
this equation on a coordinate grid. Since the formula is quadratic, the relationship between height
and time spent in the air has the shape of a parabola. So what does it tell us about MJ's dunk? Well, the parabola's vertex shows us
his maximum height off the ground at 1.038 meters, and the X-intercepts tell us 
when he took off and when he landed,
with the difference being the hang time. It looks like Earth's gravity
makes it pretty hard for even MJ to get some solid hang time. But what if he were playing an away game
somewhere else, somewhere far? Well, the gravitational acceleration
on our nearest planetary neighbor, Venus, is 8.87 meters per second squared, 
pretty similar to Earth's. If Michael jumped here with the same
force as he did back on Earth, he would be able to get more 
than a meter off the ground, giving him a hang time 
of a little over one second. The competition on Jupiter
with its gravitational pull of 24.92 meters per second squared
would be much less entertaining. Here, Michael wouldn't even
get a half meter off the ground, and would remain airborne
a mere .41 seconds. But a game on the moon
would be quite spectacular. MJ could take off from behind half court, jumping over six meters high, and his hang time of over 
five and half seconds, would be long enough for anyone
to believe he could fly.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The equation 0=-4.9(0)^2+4.51(0)represents which moment in Michael Jordan’s free-throw dunk?
Options: A. The moment he takes off, B. The moment he is at his highest point in the air, C. The moment he dunks the ball through the hoop, D. The moment he lands
Correct Option: A

Question 1: What is the name of the scientist who helped us understand that what goes up must eventually come down? Options: A. Albert Einstein, B. Isaac Newton, C. Galileo Galilei, D. Michael Jordan Correct Option: B
Question 2: According to the transcript, what is the human limit on a flat surface for hang time? Options: A. 2 seconds, B. 1 second, C. 3 seconds, D. 4 seconds Correct Option: B
Question 3: If Michael Jordan were to jump on the moon, how long would his hang time be? Options: A. Less than 1 second, B. 1-2 seconds, C. 2-3 seconds, D. Over 5 seconds Correct Option: D
Question 4: What is the gravitational acceleration on Earth? Options: A. 8.87 meters per second squared, B. 9.8 meters per second squared, C. 10.5 meters per second squared, D. 11.2 meters per second squared Correct Option: B
Question 5: According to the transcript, what is the equation that models hang time? Options: A. h = v0t + 0.5gt^2, B. h = v0t - 0.5gt^2, C. h = v0t + gt^2, D. h = v0t - gt^2 Correct Option: A

He would be able to get more hang time on Jupiter than on any other planet, C. He would be able to get more hang time on Venus than on Earth, D. Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 12, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Maybe you've recently seen the phrase
"gluten-free" on food packaging, or take-out menus, shampoo bottles,
apartment listings, the tag of your shirt, on a hammer, as a lower back tattoo,
or in your friend's resume. Next time someone starts telling you
about their newfound freedom from gluten, here are some questions you can ask, and the well-informed answers
that your friend, being a reasonable individual
making educated dietary choices, and by no means just following 
the latest diet craze, will tell you. What is gluten? Gluten is an insoluble protein composite made up of two proteins 
named gliadin and glutenin. Where might you encounter gluten? Gluten is found in certain grains,
particularly wheat, rye and barley. What has gluten been doing for
the previous entirety of human history, and why do you suddenly care about it? Gluten is responsible 
for the elastic consistency of dough and the chewiness of foods 
made from wheat flour, like bread and pasta. For some people, 
these foods cause problems, namely wheat allergy, celiac disease,
and non-celiac gluten sensitivity. Wheat allergy is an uncommon condition that occurs when a person's immune system mounts an allergic response 
to wheat proteins, leading to mild problems,
and in rare cases, a potential dangerous reaction
called anaphylaxis. Celiac disease is an inherited disease, in which eating foods with gluten leads to inflammation and damage
of the lining of the small intestine. This impairs intestinal function, leading to problems like belly pain,
bloating, gas, diarrhea, weight loss, skin rash, bone problems
like osteoporosis, iron deficiency, small stature, 
infertility, fatigue and depression. Untreated, celiac disease 
increases the risk of developing certain types of cancer. Celiac disease is present in one 
in every 100 to 200 persons in the U.S. When blood tests suggest 
the possibility of celiac, the diagnosis is confirmed with a biopsy. The most effective treatment
is a gluten-free diet, which helps heal intestinal damage
and improve symptoms. Some people don't have celiac disease
or a wheat allergy, but still experience symptoms
when they eat foods with gluten. These people have non-celiac
gluten sensitivity. They experience painful gut symptoms and suffer from fatigue, brain fog,
joint pain or skin rash. A gluten-free diet typically helps
with these symptoms. So how many people actually
have this gluten sensitivity you speak of? Gluten sensitivity's occurrence 
in the general population is unclear, but likely much more common
than wheat allergy or celiac disease. Diagnosis is based 
on the development of symptoms, the absence of wheat allergy
and celiac disease, and subsequent improvement
on a gluten-free diet. There's no reliable blood or tissue test, partly because gluten sensitivity
isn't a single disease, and has a number 
of different possible causes. For example, it may be the case that gluten can activate the immune system
in the small intestine, or cause it to become leaky. But sometimes, people claiming
gluten sensitivity are actually sensitive 
not to wheat proteins, but sugars found in wheat and other foods,
called fructans. The human intestine can't break down
or absorb fructans, so they make their way 
to the large intestine or colon, where they're fermented by bacteria, producing short-chain fatty acids
and gases. This leads to unpleasant symptoms
in some people with bowel problems. Another possible explanation behind
gluten sensitivity is the nocebo effect. This occurs when a person believes
something will cause problems, and because of that belief, it does. It's the opposite of the more well-known
and much more fortuitous placebo effect. Given how much bad press 
gluten is getting in the media, the nocebo response may play a role for some people who think
they're sensitive to gluten. For all these reasons, it's clear that 
the problems people develop when they eat wheat and other grains
aren't exclusively due to gluten. So a better name than
non-celiac gluten sensitivty might be wheat intolerance.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Gluten can be found in which type of grains?
Options: A. Wheat, B. Rye, C. Barley, D. All of the above
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is gluten? Options: A. A type of carbohydrate found in grains, B. An insoluble protein composite made up of two proteins named gliadin and glutenin, C. A type of fiber found in wheat flour, D. A type of sugar found in wheat and other foods Correct Option: B
Question 2: What are some common symptoms of celiac disease? Options: A. Belly pain, bloating, gas, diarrhea, weight loss, skin rash, bone problems, iron deficiency, small stature, infertility, fatigue, and depression, B. Mild problems and potential anaphylaxis, C. Unpleasant symptoms in the large intestine or colon, D. Joint pain or skin rash Correct Option: A
Question 3: What is the most effective treatment for celiac disease? Options: A. A gluten-free diet, B. Blood tests, C. A biopsy, D. Medication Correct Option: A
Question 4: What is non-celiac gluten sensitivity? Options: A. A condition where a person's immune system mounts an allergic response to wheat proteins, B. A condition where a person experiences painful gut symptoms and suffers from fatigue, brain fog, joint pain, or skin rash when they eat foods with gluten, C. A condition where a person is sensitive to sugars found in wheat and other foods, D. A condition where a person experiences unpleasant symptoms in the large intestine or colon Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is the nocebo effect? Options: A. The opposite of the placebo effect, B. A condition where a person experiences unpleasant symptoms in the large intestine or colon, C. A condition where a person is sensitive to sugars found in wheat and other foods, D. A condition where a person's immune system mounts an allergic response to wheat proteins Correct Option: A
Question 6: Why is diagnosis of gluten sensitivity unclear? Options: A. Because gluten sensitivity is a single disease, B. Because there's no reliable blood or tissue test, C. Because gluten sensitivity is a rare condition, D. Because gluten sensitivity is a common condition Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is fructans? Options: A. A type of carbohydrate found in grains, B. A type of fiber found in wheat flour, C. A type of sugar found in wheat and other foods, D. A type of protein found in wheat and other foods Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is the placebo effect? Options: A. The opposite of the nocebo effect, B. A condition where a person experiences unpleasant symptoms in the large intestine or colon, C. A condition where a person is sensitive to sugars found in wheat and other foods, D. A condition where a person's immune system mounts an allergic response to wheat proteins Correct Option: A
Question 9: Why might people who claim gluten sensitivity actually be sensitive to sugars found in wheat and other foods? Options: A. Because they have a wheat allergy, B. Because they have celiac disease, C. Because they have a nocebo response, D. Because their intestine can't break down or absorb fructans Correct Option: D
Question 10: What might be a better name than non-celiac gluten sensitivity? Options: A. Wheat intolerance, B. Celiac disease, C. Wheat allergy, D. Gluten sensitivity Correct Option: A


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs exactly match the ground truth MCQ. However, based on the question intent, options, and content, the most similar generated MCQ would be:

Question 1: What is gluten? Options: A. A type of carbohydrate found in grains, B. An insoluble protein composite made up of two proteins named gliadin and glutenin, C. A type of fiber found in wheat flour, D. A type of sugar found in wheat and other foods Correct Option: B

However, this question does not ask about the type of grains that contain gluten. A more suitable question would be one that asks about the types of grains containing gluten, but such a question is not present among the generated MCQs.

If I had to choose the most similar question based on the information provided, I would suggest Question 1, but with the caveat that it does not exactly match the ground truth MCQ.

However, since none of the questions match the ground truth MCQ, I would recommend creating a new question that exactly matches the ground truth MCQ.

But if I really had to choose one, I would say Question 1 is the closest, but it's not a perfect match.

Index: 1

"gluten-free" on food packaging, or take-out menus, shampoo bottles,
apartment listings, the tag of your shirt, on a hammer, as a lower back tattoo,

about their newfound freedom from gluten, here are some questions you can ask, and the well-informed answers
that your friend, being a reasonable individual
making educated dietary choices, and by no means just following 
the latest diet craze, will tell you. What is gluten? Gluten is an insoluble protein composite made up of two proteins

for the elastic consistency of dough and the chewiness of foods

and non-celiac gluten sensitivity. Wheat allergy is an uncommon condition that occurs when a person's immune system mounts an allergic response 
to wheat proteins, leading to mild problems,
and in rare cases, a potential dangerous reaction
called anaphylaxis. Celiac disease is an inherited disease, in which eating foods with gluten leads to inflammation and damage
of the lining of the small intestine. This impairs intestinal function, leading to problems like belly pain,
bloating, gas, diarrhea, weight loss, skin rash, bone problems
like osteoporosis, iron deficiency, small stature, 
infertility, fatigue and depression. Untreated, celiac disease 
increases the risk of developing certain types of cancer. Celiac disease is present in one 
in every 100 to 200 persons in the U.S. When blood tests suggest 
the possibility of celiac, the diagnosis is confirmed with a biopsy. The most effective treatment
is a gluten-free diet, which helps heal intestinal damage
and improve symptoms. Some people don't have celiac disease
or a wheat allergy, but still experience symptoms
when they eat foods with gluten. These people have non-celiac
gluten sensitivity. They experience painful gut symptoms and suffer from fatigue, brain fog,
joint pain or skin rash. A gluten-free diet typically helps
with these symptoms. So how many people actually
have this gluten sensitivity you speak of? Gluten sensitivity's occurrence 
in the general population is unclear, but likely much more common
than wheat allergy or celiac disease. Diagnosis is based 
on the development of symptoms, the absence of wheat allergy
and celiac disease, and subsequent improvement
on a gluten-free diet. There's no reliable blood or tissue test, partly because gluten sensitivity
isn't a single disease, and has a number 
of different possible causes. For example, it may be the case that gluten can activate the immune system
in the small intestine, or cause it to become leaky. But sometimes, people claiming
gluten sensitivity are actually sensitive 
not to wheat proteins, but sugars found in wheat and other foods,
called fructans. The human intestine can't break down
or absorb fructans, so they make their way 
to the large intestine or colon, where they're fermented by bacteria, producing short-chain fatty acids
and gases. This leads to unpleasant symptoms
in some people with bowel problems. Another possible explanation behind
gluten sensitivity is the nocebo effect. This occurs when a person believes
something will cause problems, and because of that belief, it does. It's the opposite of the more well-known
and much more fortuitous placebo effect. Given how much bad press 
gluten is getting in the media, the nocebo response may play a role for some people who think
they're sensitive to gluten. For all these reasons, it's clear that 
the problems people develop when they eat wheat and other grains
aren't exclusively due to gluten. So a better name than
non-celiac gluten sensitivty might be wheat intolerance.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The human intenstines cannot break down or absorb fructans which leads to:
Options: A. Fermentation by bacteria, B. Production of short chain fatty acids and gases, C. Both A and B, D. None of the above
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is gluten? Options: A. A type of carbohydrate found in grains, B. An insoluble protein composite made up of two proteins named gliadin and glutenin, C. A type of fiber found in wheat flour, D. A type of sugar found in wheat and other foods Correct Option: B
Question 2: What are some common symptoms of celiac disease? Options: A. Belly pain, bloating, gas, diarrhea, weight loss, skin rash, bone problems, iron deficiency, small stature, infertility, fatigue, and depression, B. Mild problems and potential anaphylaxis, C. Unpleasant symptoms in the large intestine or colon, D. Joint pain or skin rash Correct Option: A
Question 3: What is the most effective treatment for celiac disease? Options: A. A gluten-free diet, B. Blood tests, C. A biopsy, D. Medication Correct Option: A
Question 4: What is non-celiac gluten sensitivity? Options: A. A condition where a person's immune system mounts an allergic response to wheat proteins, B. A condition where a person experiences painful gut symptoms and suffers from fatigue, brain fog, joint pain, or skin rash when they eat foods with gluten, C. A condition where a person is sensitive to sugars found in wheat and other foods, D. A condition where a person experiences unpleasant symptoms in the large intestine or colon Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is the nocebo effect? Options: A. The opposite of the placebo effect, B. A condition where a person experiences unpleasant symptoms in the large intestine or colon, C. A condition where a person is sensitive to sugars found in wheat and other foods, D. A condition where a person's immune system mounts an allergic response to wheat proteins Correct Option: A
Question 6: Why is diagnosis of gluten sensitivity unclear? Options: A. Because gluten sensitivity is a single disease, B. Because there's no reliable blood or tissue test, C. Because gluten sensitivity is a rare condition, D. Because gluten sensitivity is a common condition Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is fructans? Options: A. A type of carbohydrate found in grains, B. A type of fiber found in wheat flour, C. A type of sugar found in wheat and other foods, D. A type of protein found in wheat and other foods Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is the placebo effect? Options: A. The opposite of the nocebo effect, B. A condition where a person experiences unpleasant symptoms in the large intestine or colon, C. A condition where a person is sensitive to sugars found in wheat and other foods, D. A condition where a person's immune system mounts an allergic response to wheat proteins Correct Option: A
Question 9: Why might people who claim gluten sensitivity actually be sensitive to sugars found in wheat and other foods? Options: A. Because they have a wheat allergy, B. Because they have celiac disease, C. Because they have a nocebo response, D. Because their intestine can't break down or absorb fructans Correct Option: D
Question 10: What might be a better name than non-celiac gluten sensitivity? Options: A. Wheat intolerance, B. Celiac disease, C. Wheat allergy, D. Gluten sensitivity Correct Option: A

Matching Response:

Because they have celiac disease, C. Because they have a nocebo response, D. Because their intestine can't break down or absorb fructans Correct Option: D**

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 12, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Maybe you've recently seen the phrase
"gluten-free" on food packaging, or take-out menus, shampoo bottles,
apartment listings, the tag of your shirt, on a hammer, as a lower back tattoo,
or in your friend's resume. Next time someone starts telling you
about their newfound freedom from gluten, here are some questions you can ask, and the well-informed answers
that your friend, being a reasonable individual
making educated dietary choices, and by no means just following 
the latest diet craze, will tell you. What is gluten? Gluten is an insoluble protein composite made up of two proteins 
named gliadin and glutenin. Where might you encounter gluten? Gluten is found in certain grains,
particularly wheat, rye and barley. What has gluten been doing for
the previous entirety of human history, and why do you suddenly care about it? Gluten is responsible 
for the elastic consistency of dough and the chewiness of foods 
made from wheat flour, like bread and pasta. For some people, 
these foods cause problems, namely wheat allergy, celiac disease,
and non-celiac gluten sensitivity. Wheat allergy is an uncommon condition that occurs when a person's immune system mounts an allergic response 
to wheat proteins, leading to mild problems,
and in rare cases, a potential dangerous reaction
called anaphylaxis. Celiac disease is an inherited disease, in which eating foods with gluten leads to inflammation and damage
of the lining of the small intestine. This impairs intestinal function, leading to problems like belly pain,
bloating, gas, diarrhea, weight loss, skin rash, bone problems
like osteoporosis, iron deficiency, small stature, 
infertility, fatigue and depression. Untreated, celiac disease 
increases the risk of developing certain types of cancer. Celiac disease is present in one 
in every 100 to 200 persons in the U.S. When blood tests suggest 
the possibility of celiac, the diagnosis is confirmed with a biopsy. The most effective treatment
is a gluten-free diet, which helps heal intestinal damage
and improve symptoms. Some people don't have celiac disease
or a wheat allergy, but still experience symptoms
when they eat foods with gluten. These people have non-celiac
gluten sensitivity. They experience painful gut symptoms and suffer from fatigue, brain fog,
joint pain or skin rash. A gluten-free diet typically helps
with these symptoms. So how many people actually
have this gluten sensitivity you speak of? Gluten sensitivity's occurrence 
in the general population is unclear, but likely much more common
than wheat allergy or celiac disease. Diagnosis is based 
on the development of symptoms, the absence of wheat allergy
and celiac disease, and subsequent improvement
on a gluten-free diet. There's no reliable blood or tissue test, partly because gluten sensitivity
isn't a single disease, and has a number 
of different possible causes. For example, it may be the case that gluten can activate the immune system
in the small intestine, or cause it to become leaky. But sometimes, people claiming
gluten sensitivity are actually sensitive 
not to wheat proteins, but sugars found in wheat and other foods,
called fructans. The human intestine can't break down
or absorb fructans, so they make their way 
to the large intestine or colon, where they're fermented by bacteria, producing short-chain fatty acids
and gases. This leads to unpleasant symptoms
in some people with bowel problems. Another possible explanation behind
gluten sensitivity is the nocebo effect. This occurs when a person believes
something will cause problems, and because of that belief, it does. It's the opposite of the more well-known
and much more fortuitous placebo effect. Given how much bad press 
gluten is getting in the media, the nocebo response may play a role for some people who think
they're sensitive to gluten. For all these reasons, it's clear that 
the problems people develop when they eat wheat and other grains
aren't exclusively due to gluten. So a better name than
non-celiac gluten sensitivty might be wheat intolerance.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: When a person believes something will cause problems and because of that belief, it does, it is called:
Options: A. Bad press, B. A placebo effect, C. Sensitivity, D. Nocebo effect
Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 13, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
[MUSIC PLAYING] Getting sick
stinks-- literally. What I mean is that
different diseases give off different odors, and sometimes
doctors can diagnose you based on how you smell. I'm Anna Rothschild, and
this is "Gross Science." So it turns out
that doctors have known since the
time of Hippocrates that different diseases
smell different ways. For example,
typhoid-- which causes fever, abdominal pain,
delirium, and can kill you-- smells like freshly
baked brown bread. Other infections smell
totally differently. The skin of people with
the virus yellow fever is said to smell
like a butcher shop. And if you have a burn wound
infected with the bacteria Pseudomonas, it might
smell like grape juice. But infections from
bacteria and viruses aren't the only
diseases that can make you emit a certain aroma. Genetic conditions--
ones you're born with-- can do the same thing. For example, maple
syrup urine disease, which can be fatal
if untreated, makes you smell like maple syrup. And then there's a condition
called Trimethylaminuria, which has absolutely no
symptoms, except that it makes you smell like rotten fish. And those are just diseases
that humans can smell. Dogs can actually sniff out
certain types of cancer, and scientists have now
created electronic noses. These are smelling
machines that can detect very faint
traces of compounds that the human nose would
never be able to pick up. Beep boop beep. In fact, researchers are looking
into using dogs or e-noses to detect diseases before
they become dangerous. So while sniffing out
the source of an illness has never really
gone away, there's a whole new frontier of
stench science out there. Just take a whiff. Ew. What's the grossest thing
you've ever smelled? Let me know in the comments. And for more "Gross Science"
and weird facts, hit Subscribe.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: True or False: Diseases from bacteria and viruses are the only diseases that give off smells.
Options: A. True, B. False
Correct Option: B

Question 5: What is the name of the condition that makes a person smell like rotten fish, but has no other symptoms? Options: A. Maple syrup urine disease, B. Trimethylaminuria, C. Typhoid, D. Yellow fever Correct Option: B

Question 7: What is the purpose of using electronic noses in research? Options: A. To diagnose diseases based on smell, B. To detect very faint traces of compounds, C. To create new medicines, D. To study the effects of climate change Correct Option: B
Question 8: Why are researchers looking into using dogs or e-noses to detect diseases? Options: A. To improve the accuracy of diagnosis, B. To reduce the cost of treatment, C. To detect diseases before they become dangerous, D. To create new jobs in the medical field Correct Option: C

The benefits of using electronic noses to detect diseases, D. The dangers of genetic conditions Correct Option: B

that doctors have known since the

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 13, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
[MUSIC PLAYING] Getting sick
stinks-- literally. What I mean is that
different diseases give off different odors, and sometimes
doctors can diagnose you based on how you smell. I'm Anna Rothschild, and
this is "Gross Science." So it turns out
that doctors have known since the
time of Hippocrates that different diseases
smell different ways. For example,
typhoid-- which causes fever, abdominal pain,
delirium, and can kill you-- smells like freshly
baked brown bread. Other infections smell
totally differently. The skin of people with
the virus yellow fever is said to smell
like a butcher shop. And if you have a burn wound
infected with the bacteria Pseudomonas, it might
smell like grape juice. But infections from
bacteria and viruses aren't the only
diseases that can make you emit a certain aroma. Genetic conditions--
ones you're born with-- can do the same thing. For example, maple
syrup urine disease, which can be fatal
if untreated, makes you smell like maple syrup. And then there's a condition
called Trimethylaminuria, which has absolutely no
symptoms, except that it makes you smell like rotten fish. And those are just diseases
that humans can smell. Dogs can actually sniff out
certain types of cancer, and scientists have now
created electronic noses. These are smelling
machines that can detect very faint
traces of compounds that the human nose would
never be able to pick up. Beep boop beep. In fact, researchers are looking
into using dogs or e-noses to detect diseases before
they become dangerous. So while sniffing out
the source of an illness has never really
gone away, there's a whole new frontier of
stench science out there. Just take a whiff. Ew. What's the grossest thing
you've ever smelled? Let me know in the comments. And for more "Gross Science"
and weird facts, hit Subscribe.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: True or False: Diseases from bacteria and viruses are the only diseases that give off smells.
Options: A. True, B. False
Correct Option: B
